The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
THE weight of this illu≈øtrious Subject might have required a greater ∆≤ndertaker, and made me have kept at an awfull di≈øtance, whil≈øt the mo≈øt celebrated Pens of Europe had interwoven and enamell'd the Birth and Ri≈øing, Glories of ≈øo great a Prince, with all the Rhetorical and Heroick Accents and Expre≈ø≈øions that are capable of giving Life and Fire to the Minds of Men, and rai≈øing their Souls to a highth capable of knowing the Centre of true Greatne≈øs; but with humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, not finding any forward in ≈øo invaluable an Enterprize, I, though unworthy, have pre≈øumed to
make this E≈ø≈øay, hoping it will not be taken ill, ≈øince this, at lea≈øt, is the Ground-work, upon which the mo≈øt a≈øpiring Hi≈øtorian mu≈øt build, when he con≈øults the Golden Rolls of Fame to rai≈øe a Pyramid of la≈øting Honour to the Memories of the World's undoubted Worthies. In this Book, though ≈ømall to appearance, you may find things as va≈øt in Extent as Virtue and Valour can enlarge them; and when I tell you it is the Compendium of the Birth and Actions of the Great and Renowned Prince of the Hou≈øe of Orange, with what more e≈øpecially relates to his Redeeming us from Popery and Slavery, by his generous Expedition, Valour, and Conduct, I might be ≈øilent, ≈øince the World is ≈øufficiently ≈øen≈øible of what I farther intend; yet that Po≈øterity may not forget ≈øo great a Deliverance, it is fit that it ≈øhould be Recorded till Time is ≈øwallowed up in Eternity.

You have, Reader, in this Book an
Account of the illu≈øtrious Birth of a Prince, born to be the Protectour of the true Religion, and the Support (next the Almighty Arm) of Chri≈øtianity, coming neare≈øt to its primitive Purity, with his Advancement to early Honours, and his memorable Actions from time to time, with the various dangers and hazards to which he has expo≈øed him≈øelf, for the Repo≈øe of Chri≈øtendom, but more e≈øpecially for the ≈øecuring and promoting the Prote≈øtant Religion. You have likewi≈øe a Di≈øcovery of Popi≈øh Cruelties, in the wretched State and Condition of the Prote≈øtants in France, under the late Per≈øecution, from which you may gather what we might have expected and ≈øuffered, had not this great Prince at ≈øo much Co≈øt, hazard of his Per≈øon, and indefatigable Labour and Indu≈øtry, di≈øpell'd with the Rays of his early and glorious Succe≈øs, the cloudy Tempest that was breaking over our Heads; and to be brief, you have an
Account of all that has memorably pa≈ø≈øed from his Birth to this day, and that more particularly in England, upon the ever-to-be-remembered Occa≈øion of his coming over as our Protectour and Deliverer, with the indefatigable Indu≈øtry he has ≈øucce≈øsfully u≈øed to infatuate and defeat the De≈øigns of our Enemies, and the Returns he has found from a ≈øen≈øible and gratefull People, and e≈øpecially the Wi≈ødom of the Nation A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, in Proclaiming and Crowning him, together with his Royal Con≈øort, King and Queen of England, &c. with the manner of the performance, and what el≈øe can be required to ≈øet forth ≈øo illu≈øtrious an History, the Subject of which may ≈øome Angel ≈øound with a golden Trumpet to the utmo≈øt Kingdoms of the Earth: which is the Wi≈øh of

div.head: An Hi≈øtorical Account of the Life and memorable Actions of the mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious William Henry, King of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, Prince of Orange, &c.
div.p:
WHen we undertake to Write of illu≈øtrious Per≈øons, who≈øe great Actions are ≈øufficiently known to the World, and who≈øe Vertues and Candour have placed them upon a Pinacle of Fame, it is then that Rhetorical Strains, or flattering Applau≈øe, is altogether to be laid a≈øide, as vain and u≈øele≈øs; for true Diamonds require not the Art to ≈øet them off, like Counterfeits, but relying upon their proper Lu≈øtre make their value known, and ≈øhine in a kind of carele≈øs Glory; wherefore con≈øidering the Illu≈øtrious Subject I am here to handle, waving elaborate Circum≈øtances, and Expre≈ø≈øions not greatly
pertinent to Hi≈øtory, or Matters of this kind; my Care and Endeavour ≈øhall be to keep to Truth and Fact, and as much as in me lies to give a ≈øatisfactory Account of the Birth and glorious Actions of a Prince, who≈øe Fame has travell'd with the Sun.

WIlliam Henry, of the Illu≈øtrious Hou≈øe of Na≈ø≈øau, our pre≈øent Sovereign, de≈øcended from that renowned German Family, that has been ever Famous, and to which the Empire and all Chri≈øtendom has been ≈øo much beholden, Son to William of Na≈ø≈øau, Prince of Orange, by the Royal Prince≈øs Mary, Daughter to Charles I. King of England, &c. was Born on the 14th. of November, in the year of our Lord, 1650. his Father dying the preceding Month, after he had been Married about nine Years, and done Actions worthy of his high Birth, in the Four and Twentieth year of his Age, leaving this hopefull, I≈ø≈øue to di≈øpell the Clouds of Sorrow that began to ≈øpread them≈øelves over mo≈øt European Courts, upon notice of a Death ≈øo unexpected, and a Lo≈øs ≈øo important.

This great Prince at his Bapti≈øm had
for Godfathers the Lords States of Holland, Zealand, and the Cities of Am≈øterdam, Delf, and Leyden, receiving the Name of William Henry; and as he increa≈øed in years, under the Care of the indulgent Prince≈øs, and ≈øuch as were appointed to attend and wait upon him, he gave early hope of what hath ≈øince been ≈øufficiently manife≈øted.

At five years of Age he came to vi≈øit his Uncle, King Charles II who then was at Breda, preparing for England, to take Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Thrones and Kingdoms, ≈øo long detained from him; where the King expre≈ø≈øed his extraordinary ≈øatisfaction to ≈øee the Prince his Nephew, and highly welcomed him; and ≈øoon after the E≈øtates General, having a particular Audience of the King, recommending the firmne≈øs and fidelity of that Republick to his Intere≈øt, &c. his Maje≈øty in the mo≈øt obliging Terms replyed, That the Intere≈øt, if no other Motives ≈øhould induce him to it, of two Per≈øons ≈øo nearly allied to him, as the Prince≈øs Royal his Si≈øter, and the Prince of Orange his Nephew, who live in the E≈øtate as part of it, mu≈øt unavoidably endear it to him. However, there were many Rea≈øons of State, which obliged him to make with tho≈øe Provinces a mo≈øt
≈øtrict Alliance: And now the King's Departure for England being at hand, the E≈øtates General named Mr. De Gent. Deputy of Guelderland, Guelderwagen of Holland, and Lamp≈øins of Zeland, to wait upon the Queen of Bohemia, who was then with the King, and the Duke of York, and Gloucester, who Lodged in the Extroardinary Amba≈ø≈øador's Hou≈øe, to complement them on the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the King, and the Revolution of the Affairs of England; and at the ≈øame time Mr. Ren≈øwonde of Utreicht, Ripperdo of Hengelo, of Overy≈øel, together with Isbrants of Groning, were deputed to the ≈øame Office, by the Prince≈øs Royal, and the Prince of Orange.

The King being treated by the E≈øtates General at the Hague, he ≈øitting at the middle of the Table-head, had on the Right Hand the Queen of Bohemia, on the Left the Prince≈øs Royal, and there the Prince was pre≈øent, a Seat being placed on purpo≈øe for him to di≈øtingui≈øh his Character, though in his tender years, from Lords of great Rank and Quality, who were pre≈øent at that ≈øplendid Entertainment; and this order was ob≈øerved whenever he Dined publickly with the King, which he frequently
did, as well at the Hague, as at other places; and when the King left the Hague, his Highne≈øs, accompanied with Prince William of Na≈ø≈øau, Governour of Friezeland, with ≈øundry Nobles and Gentlemen, went before him towards the Ships, on which, together with his Train, he was to embark for England; and when he went on Board he was conducted to the Admiral's Ship by the Queen of Bohemia, the Prince≈øs Royal, and the Prince of Orange, to whom at his Departure he returned mo≈øt obliging Thanks, and endearing Expre≈ø≈øions of Affection, which ended not but with his Life. The≈øe were the remarkable Pa≈ø≈øages (as I may term them) in the Infancy of this great Prince: But it is time to go on to tho≈øe of his riper years.

A prevailing Faction growing up in the United Provinces, managed by State≈ømen that ambitiou≈øly ≈øtrove to engro≈øs the Power, and enrich them≈øelves as much as in them lay, to over≈øhadow the Brightne≈øs of this Ri≈øing Sun, to eclip≈øe the Family that had laid the very Foundation of the State, and by which Providence would have it ≈øupported, though at the ≈øame time France pre≈ø≈øed them with a prevailing Army.
Among≈øt tho≈øe of the Faction, the De Wits were very forward, for which, and ≈øome underhand Practices again≈øt the Per≈øon of the Prince, the two Brothers, John and Cornelius, ≈øoon after felt the Rage of the People, who out them to pieces; however tho≈øe that remained ≈øtruggled to keep them≈øelves in Power; and the better to doe it, disbanded their experienced Forces and Officers, putting in their ≈øteads the Sons of Burgher-ma≈øters, and ≈øuch others as they ≈øuppo≈øed would ≈øtickle for them again≈øt the Intere≈øt, of this Ri≈øing Prince; however it la≈øted not, for within a while the French taking more effectually the advantage of this over≈øight, ≈øwept away divers of the Frontier Towns, and entered deep, with great ravagement and deva≈øtation, into ≈øome of the Provinces, which made the People con≈øider of a General to lead their Forces; whereupon in the beginning of the year 1672. the Prince was inve≈øted with the Titles of Captain, and Admiral General of the United Provinces, Honours his Ance≈øtors had a long time meritoriou≈øly enjoyed to the extraordinary contentment of the People, by having (next under God) been the chief means of reducing tho≈øe Provinces from
Slavery into a State; when his Highne≈øs, Marching at the Head of a few Troups, made good his Po≈øt at Nienkop again≈øt the violent Attacks and Incroachments of the French, and ≈øo gallantly ordered Affairs, that he made them retire with lo≈øs.

Upon the Ravage the French had made on the Frontiers, the people of the Province of Holland grew di≈øcontented and di≈øplea≈øed with their Magi≈øtrates, attributing the Mi≈øfortune to their neglect; ≈øo that tho≈øe of Dort broke into open Mutiny, demanding to ≈øee the Megazines; but being put off, or refu≈øed, ≈øu≈øpecting ≈øome Treachery, they re≈øolved to have the Prince made Stateholder, nor would they by any means be appea≈øed, till he was ≈øent for, and confirmed in that Dignity, which being pa≈ø≈øed into an Act, great joy en≈øued among≈øt the People; and ≈øoon after the other Cities and Provinces con≈øented to the like Inve≈øtment, and his Highne≈øs took his Place in the Hall of Audience, with the Ceremonies the Dignity required.

Upon the≈øe Proceedings, and his Highne≈øs's returning ‚Ä¢ o the Army at Bodegrove, the Face of things were changed, and the late drooping Provinces ≈øeemed to take new Life and Vigour; the French
were manfully re≈øi≈øted, and the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter forced from the Walls of Groning by a ≈ølender Gari≈øon, after the Lo≈øs of a great part of his Army; ≈øo that now the Prince being very powerfull in the Hearts of the people, the De Wits were ≈øacrificed to the popular Fury, for con≈øpiring again≈øt him & the Government, for the Burghers and others taking Arms, and breaking in upon them, where Cornelius was impri≈øoned by the Magi≈øtrates, and his Brother John at that time come to ≈øee him, they dragged them thence with great Cries, and after a mi≈øerable mi≈ø-u≈øage, hung them up by the Heels in the Market-place, and cutting them to pieces, ≈øold their Joints and Fle≈øh by piece-meal, at great Rates, which were carried away by the Buyers in a Triumph of Revenge.

The De Wits falling thus from their highth of Honour, Min Heer Fagel was made Pentionary with the Prince's approbation; and indeed de≈øervedly, having been the fir≈øt, when only Pentioner of Haerlem, to open peoples Eyes upon the inevitable Ruine that mu≈øt have attended upon the continuance of the De Wits Mini≈øtry, and thereupon the Elector of Brandenburgh wrote a mo≈øt obliging Letter
to the States, to let them know he had received the News of the Prince's Advancement and Settlement in the Honours and Dignities of his Ance≈øtors, and to a≈ø≈øure them of his Friend≈øhip and good Will; ≈øo that the Provinces within them≈øelves being ≈øettled, it was thought high time to oppo≈øe the In≈øults of the French; whereupon the Prince marched to di≈ølodge their Out-gaurds, and came upon them ≈øo unexpectedly and with ≈øo much terrour as they lay at the Seige of Utreicht, that he beat them into their Trenches, and took ≈øeveral Pri≈øoners of Note, which he commended to be kindly u≈øed, and ≈øent to Am≈øterdam: And now there being a Rumour that ≈øome Attempt was de≈øigned again≈øt his Highne≈øs's Per≈øon, by ≈øome private means; ≈øo far it wrought, that from that time he has been entreated to accept of a Guard for his Per≈øon, and although the ≈øea≈øon was far advanced, he laid Seige to Woerden, a con≈øiderable Gari≈øon, held by the French, to the relief of which the Duke of Luxemburgh ha≈øted, and was the fir≈øt time obliged to retire with con≈øiderable lo≈øs; but returning with a great Re-inforcement, as the Toown was about to Capitulate, after an ob≈øtinate
Fight, and many kill'd on both ≈øides, he put a ≈øuccour of 300 Men into it, and with con≈øiderable Lo≈øs retreated. This new recruit encouraging the Gari≈øon, and the Prince having lo≈øt in the Action Collonel Suyle≈øteyme (who bore the fury of the Attack, and faught valiantly, but being over-powered, and refu≈øing Quarter, was killed,) as likewi≈øe other brave Men, and now the Weather more incommoding his Army than the Enemy, he thought it convenient to ri≈øe from before it, and drew off without any mole≈øtation.

After the≈øe Proceedings, his Highne≈øs held a Council of War, and having given nece≈ø≈øary Orders, marched to Ro≈øendale, where the General Rendezvouz were appointed, and there having mu≈øtered an Army to the number of 24000. he took his March towards the Country of Liege, and obliged the Count de Duras to retire to Sta≈ø≈øemburgh with the Army he then had under his Command, being de≈øirous, if it might conveniently be, to give him Battel: but under≈øtanding that the Count frequently ≈øhifted his Quarters, in a kind of a retiring manner, the Prince after inve≈øting Tongeren with his own and ≈øuch Spani≈øh Forces as
had joyned with him; and by that means not being able to draw him to a Battel, he re-pa≈ø≈øed the Meu≈øe, and after ≈øome longer attendence to that purpo≈øe, he marched to Mae≈øtreicht, and ≈øent a Party of Hor≈øe and Foot to take in the Ca≈øtle of Valcheren, which ≈øoon ≈øurrendred upon di≈øcretion; and there they found a con≈øiderable Megazine, e≈øpecially of Forage: And after that his Highne≈øs having inve≈øted Charleroy without ≈øucce≈øs, by rea≈øon of the ≈øharpne≈øs of the Weather, and taken Birch, an important Place, defended by three Captains, and 300. Soldiers, Demoli≈øhing the Town, he marched through Brabant, and put his Soldiers into Winter Quarters.

During the≈øe Tran≈øactions, the French in con≈øiderable Parties taking the advantage of the hard Fro≈øt, marched over the Ice, and made ≈øome incon≈øiderable ≈øpoil in the Villages, but upon the approach of his Highne≈øs they retired in di≈øorder, with con≈øiderable lo≈øs; and had the Pa≈ø≈øes been defended as the States directed, mo≈øt of them had peri≈øhed in the Waters, by rea≈øon of the ≈øudden Thaw that en≈øued. About this time, to make amends for the mi≈øchief the French had done Coeverden, was recovered
covered a Place of great importance, and from whence the Gari≈øon-Soldiers, by their frequent Inroads, had greatly endamaged the Country. And now his Highne≈øs indu≈øtriou≈øly laboured to compo≈øe home-bred Differences and Di≈øcords, which he effected with the ≈øame facility that attended all his undertakings, in≈øomuch that all Animo≈øities were laid a≈øide, and every Man apply'd him≈øelf to promote the publick good of the Country; and then he proceeded to vi≈øit the Fortifications, and give ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary Orders, as the Juncture of Affairs required.

The Spring advancing, the French King made great preparations again≈øt Holland, invading them in Per≈øon with a powerfull Army, whil≈øt the Prince of Conde and Duke of Luxemburgh were encamped at Utriecht, expecting Orders to fall into the County. They had now likewi≈øe War with the King of Great Britain, with who≈øe powerfull Navy the French joyn'd; which made the the Prince to be very carefull in attending the motion of the French by Land, whil≈øt the States prepared to ≈øet out their Naval Forces; nor was ≈øuch a Storm as then threatened the Provinces, to be
≈ølightly regarded; for the French King laid Siege to Mae≈øtriecht, with an Army of 42000 Hor≈øe and Foot, on the 10th. of June, it being before blocked up by the Count De l' Orge, with three thou≈øand Hor≈øe: In this place was a Gari≈øon of about eight or nine hundred Hor≈øe, and four thou≈øand Foot, Commanded by the valiant Mon≈øieur d' Fariaux, who defended the place with much Bravery to the la≈øt extremity, killing the French about 9000 Soldiers, be≈øides Officers, and Men of great note; and then at the Petition and earne≈øt Intreaty of the Inhabitants, ≈øurrendered upon honourable terms, and was ≈øoon after, for his Courage and prudent Conduct, made, by his Highne≈øs, Major General of the Army: And at this Seige it was that the unfortunate Duke of Monmouth ≈øignalized his Valour to the highth of Bravery; by which, and the Courage of the Engli≈øh under his Command, the French King may be ju≈øtly ≈øaid to make him≈øelf Ma≈øter of this Place; after which, the French Army being drawn off, and partly di≈øper≈øed; the Prince drew together his Forces, and laid Siege to Maerd, ≈øtraitening it with 25000 Hor≈øe and Foot, which obliged the Duke of Luxemburgh
to bend his Forces that way; however the Place was taken without much difficulty in four days, and Luxemburgh retired.

About this time the States entred into a League, with the Emperour and King of Spain again≈øt France, who≈øe Armies joyning, at lea≈øt in part, the Seige of Bonne was pitch'd upon, into which the Prince of Conde had only the advantage of putting 100 Hor≈øe, who pa≈ø≈øed the Centinels under pretence of being the Duke of Lorrain's Party, and 100 more attempting to doe the like through the Prince's Quarters, not only failed of ≈øucce≈øs, but were mo≈øt of them killed and taken Pri≈øoners, and 500 more, who were to ≈øupport them, obliged to retreat being beholden for their ≈øafety to the ≈øwiftne≈øs of their Hor≈øes: And now the Town was clo≈øely pre≈ø≈øed by the confederate Army, and the Governour ≈øummoned; and although at the fir≈øt he refu≈øed, yet perceiving the re≈øolution of the Be≈øiegers to ≈øpare none they found in Arms if the Town was taken by Storm, and the vigorous Attacks they made, at the end of ≈øeven days a Parley was beat, and the Be≈øieged granted honourable terms; they marched out to the number
of 1500, ≈øo that with little lo≈øs of Bloud the Confederates became Ma≈øters of this City; upon which the Prince of Orange drew off to We≈ø≈øeling; and commanding in the ab≈øence of Montecuculi the Imperial Army, he ≈øeized on the Ca≈øtles of Lechnich and Brevel; and now Succe≈øs attending his Sword, he con≈øtrained the French, although Turene had taken the Field with a con≈øiderable Army, to quit many Places they conceived not to be tenable, or at lea≈øt ways to draw out the Gari≈øons to recruit their Army, which was not in a condition to make head again≈øt the Confederates: Among≈øt tho≈øe that they quitted was Herderwick, Woerden, Utreicht, Bomniel, Campen, Elburg, and Hattein, and the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter, who was in League with France, quitted Mempel and Stenwick; yet at their Departure they exacted great Summes of Mony from the Inhabitants in lieu of their not firing the Hou≈øes; yet they di≈ømantled many of them, and left vi≈øible tokens of their Anger, for being con≈øtrained to quit tho≈øe important Places which they had gained at at a va≈øt expence of Bloud and Trea≈øure. So far did the terrour of a young General in this Ri≈øing Glories
work upon the minds of this late in≈øulting Nation, that they who had lately carried Ruine and Deva≈øtation into the nighbouring Country, began now to ≈øhrink together in their own.

The≈øe were the principal Tran≈øactions to the end of the year 1673. and in gratitude for the Services his Highne≈øs had done the States by his Valour and Conduct, in freeing them from the Danger of their capital Enemies, and recovering ≈øo many wealthy Towns, they confirmed to him the Dignity of Stateholder, for the Provinces of Holland and We≈øt Friezeland, pa≈ø≈øing a Decree to hold it not only for his Life, but to ≈øettle it upon the Heirs Male of his Body, in lawfull Marriage, for ever. Upon which his Highne≈øs for a time, made it his Bu≈øine≈øs with indefatigable care and indu≈øtry, to ≈øettle the Province of Utreicht, and other Countrys that had been di≈øturbed, and put out of order by the Inva≈øion of the French, and made ≈øuch Reformation and good Regulation of a Government that had been ≈øhaken and put out of frame, by the ≈øundry & ≈øudden Revolutions, that he ≈øettled Matters to the admiration & content of all Per≈øons that had to doe in it, ≈øo that they unanimou≈øly voted
him Governour-General, and Captain-General of the Province of Utreicht, and the honour to de≈øcend to his Heirs Male, lawfully born in Wedlock.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things were doing, General Rebenhaupt, being aboard with a ≈øtrong Party, took Northom, and put a Gari≈øon into it, beat the Mun≈øter Forces, that in his ab≈øence were endeavouring to re-take it; and marched onward, ≈øtormed Nigenbuys, yet the Gari≈øon retiring to a little Ca≈øtle, capable of making but a ≈ølender re≈øi≈øtence, were ≈øpared upon their throwing down their Arms, and begging Quarter: But upon his going into Winter Quarters, and di≈øper≈øing his Men, General Negal, with the Mun≈øter Forces under his Command, recovered the latter. However, the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter, perceiving the Tempe≈øt of War to gather about his Countries, and finding the French King no way able to ≈øupport him, he thought it high time to treat of Peace, and accordingly clapped up one with the Emperour, which more and more di≈øcouraged the French, ≈øo that the Marque≈øs of Belefouds, who ≈øucceeded the Mare≈øchal d' Humiers in the Netherland Acqui≈øitions, thought of nothing more than the de≈øerting the Towns that yet remained.

And in order to this, upon notice that the Prince was marching into Brabant with 30000 Men to joyn the Spani≈øh Forces, Tiel, Arnheim, Zutphen, and others, were ≈ølighted, but not without great Summes of Money extorted from the Inhabitants, to ≈øave them from Plunder and Burning; the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter likewi≈øe relinqui≈øhed Devenenter, ≈øo that all Overy≈øel was at entire Liberty, and had tho≈øe Di≈øorders the Enemy occa≈øioned in Government rectified and re≈øtored by his Highne≈øs's ≈øpecial Command, though for quitting the≈øe Towns the Marque≈øs lo≈øt the French King's Favour, and was for bidden the Court, the better to colour the Bu≈øine≈øs, which his nece≈ø≈øity, pa≈øt all peradventure, had obliged him to doe; yet to repair this lo≈øs he fell into the French Conte, and took Dole, Malins, and Becan≈øon, making him≈øelf, in a ≈øhort time, Ma≈øter of that entire Province: This made his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange repair the ≈øooner to the Army at Bargen Opzoon, marching from thence to Mallins, guarding the Fronteirs of Brabant, ≈øo that the French, though abroad with two powerfull Armies, dur≈øt attempt nothing farther on that ≈øide.

The Confederate Armies joyning about the end of July, The Generals agreed, That Count Souches ≈øhould lead the Van, the Prince of Orange the Main Battel, and the Rear-Guard to be commanded by the Count Montery, and ≈øo they proceeded to oblige the Prince of Conde, who lay encamped with the greate≈øt ≈øtrength of the French power, to a Battel; but not being able to draw him to it, and perceiving the ≈øtill fortified his Camp, the Confederate Armies drew off, in order to be≈øiege and take in ≈øome Places of Importance, which Conde no ≈øooner perceived, and under≈øtanding the difficult ways they were to pa≈øs, but he drew out and pur≈øued the Rear-Guard, as knowing the Van-Guard and Main Battalia were a great way advanced, and charged the Prince of Vaudemont, who con≈øi≈øted mo≈øt of Hor≈øe, which obliged him to ≈øend to the Prince of Orange for two Battalians of Foot, who ≈øent him three, under the Command of young Prince Maurice of Na≈ø≈øau, and ≈øoon after the entire Army engaged by degrees in a doubtfull and bloudy Fight, near the River Seneff, where at fir≈øt the French had the advantage, by rea≈øon the Confederate Army being, as is ≈øaid, divided,
could not ≈øo ≈øoon unite as was convenient; however the Prince of Conde in conclu≈øion was obliged to draw off, and quit the Field, with the lo≈øs of about 7000 Men, and amon≈øt them ≈øundry great Officers and Voluntiers of note: Nor did the Confederates lo≈øe le≈øs than 6000, and among≈øt them many Noble-men, be≈øides tho≈øe that were wounded and taken Pri≈øoners on both ≈øides: And in this Battel, which la≈øted for about the ≈øpace of ≈øix or ≈øeven hours, his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange ≈øpared not to hazard his Per≈øon in the greate≈øt danger, labouring with his Voice and Example to encourage his Men, and re≈øtore the Battel where he found it broken and di≈øordered, by rallying the Troups and Battalions, cau≈øing tho≈øe that ≈øhrunk or gave back to advance, and with his Sword in his hand, led them on to face the danger, omitting nothing that became a great and experienced General; in≈øomuch that General Souches, a Man of great prudence and large under≈øtanding, gives a Character of him to the States of Holland in the≈øe words.
div.q:
I have endeavoured (≈øays he) to di≈øcharge my Duty, in attending his Highne≈øs
the Prince of Orange, during the famous, though bloudy, Battel between the Confederate Army and that of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, the happy I≈ø≈øue of which has proved very much to the Glory of the Prince, who ≈øhewed, upon that occa≈øion, the Prudence of an aged Captain, the Courage of a Cae≈øar, and the un daunted Bravery of a Marius; all which, My Lords, is delivered by me without Flattery, which is contrary to my Nature, &c.
div.p:
The Fight being over, and the Confederates with a ≈øtrong Party keeping the Field all Night, the Prince the next day marched by Mons with his whole Army, and was recruited at St. Gilain with five Dutch Regiments, and there he Quartered, whil≈øt the Imperiali≈øts marched to Queverain; when ≈øoon after General Rabenhaupt laid Siege to the Greves, a ≈øtrong Gari≈øon po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the French, and as ≈øtoutly defended, in≈øomuch that he had been undoubtedly obliged to quit that Siege, had not the Prince of Orange perfected it by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtence he gave; for the Gari≈øon con≈øi≈øted of 4000 Foot, and 9 Troups of Hor≈øe, and in it 450 pieces of Cannon, a hundred of them mounted, be≈øides a large ≈øtore of Ammunition and Provi≈øion,
yet this ≈øtrong place yielded to the unconquerable Fortune of the Prince; for finding the Imperiali≈øts and Spaniards not forward to hazard a ≈øecond Battel with Conde, who was by this time con≈øiderably re-inforced, leaving the Gro≈øs of his Army with Prince Waldeck, he came to the Siege of this place with 60 Troups of Hor≈øe, which ≈øo animated the Be≈øiegers, and daunted the Be≈øieged, that the Marque≈øs De Chamilly, Governour of the Town, finding the great Breaches that were made in the Walls, and the mi≈øchief done by the ≈øpringing of the Mines, he began to conclude it could not hold out a re≈øolute A≈ø≈øault, and ≈øo coming to a Parley, obtained honourable Conditions; by which means the Curb that this ≈øtrong Gari≈øon had put upon the nighbouring Countries was happily taken off, and the Troups for the mo≈øt part were put into Winter Quarters, and little of the Action happened till the en≈øuing Spring; yet in con≈øideration of the farther Services the Prince had done the States, they of Guelderland offered him as an addition to his other Honours, the Sovereignty of the Dutchy of Guelders, & the County of Zutphen; and though other Provinces intimated at the ≈øame time
that they would doe the like, yet he would in mode≈øty accept of no other than that of Governour Hereditary of tho≈øe Provinces; and being confirmed therein, his fir≈øt care was to ≈øettle the Affairs that had been di≈øordered, as prudently fore≈øeeing that nothing conduces more to the happine≈øs of a Country, than a good Con≈øtitution of Government.

In the year 1675 the French by their great preparations demon≈øtrating their early Intentions to take the Field, the Confederates con≈øulted the be≈øt methods for the carrying on the War again≈øt France: But whil≈øt that was doing the Prince fell ≈øick of the Small-Pox, which Di≈øtemper having proved fatal to many of his near Relations, created a ≈øadne≈øs not only throughout the Provinces, but almo≈øt every where where the news came; yet it la≈øted not; for in a ≈øhort time, through the diligence and indu≈øtry of his Phy≈øicians, great ≈øigns of Amendment appeared, which ended in a perfect recovery of his Health; when, as ≈øoon as his ≈øtrength would permit him, he ha≈øted to the general Rendezvouz, near Ro≈øendale, the better to attend the French King's motion, who was by this time in
the Field, and upon his March towards Brabant, having already be≈øieged Limburgh, by the Marque≈øs of Rochfort,

The Prince before his Departure adju≈øted and reconciled ≈øeveral Differences, and held a Conference with the Elector of Brandenburgh, who came to the Hague to pay him a Vi≈øit. Great indeed was the Spoil the French made, quite de≈øtroying the fruitfull Country of Waes, which made the Confederate Armies ha≈øten to oppo≈øe them, and the Prince being at Ro≈øendale, gave ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary Orders, as according to the mea≈øures that were then taken for carrying on the Affairs, were be≈øt ≈øuitable: After which he marched with the Army under his Command towards Mallins, upon notice the French were ≈øet down before Conde, the King in per≈øon being in the Army, who cau≈øed the Siege to be carried on with ≈øo much vigour, that before the Prince could put his De≈øigns in Execution, in order to relieve it, the Town was taken by ≈øtorm; yet Quarter, after much ≈ølaughter on both ≈øides, was given to ≈øuch as yielded, and they were made Pri≈øoners of War: And now his Highne≈øs having an Army of about 30000, daily expected 10 or 12000
Spaniards to join with him; which conjunction ≈øoon happening, he took a review of the Forces, and having an account that Bouchain was be≈øieged, and that the Governour, the better to defend it, had cau≈øed the lower Town to be burnt down; a Council of War was held, in which it was re≈øolved to rai≈øe the Siege, or give the Enemy Battel; and accordingly his Highne≈øs commanded the Prince of Vaudemont, to march privately with three thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot, to ≈øecure a Pa≈øs over the River Schelde, below Conde; and at the ≈øame time the Duke of Hol≈øtein marched with 1500 Hor≈øe, and two Regiments of Foot, through Mons towards Kieurain, to amu≈øe the Enemy, and make them believe the whole Army was coming to Attack them on that ≈øide, and thereupon all the Forces marched without beat of Drum, or ≈øound of Trumpet, in two Lines; which made the French King, who lay with his Forces at Kieurain, Soburgh, &c. to draw off, that he might cover the Siege, leaving the Mare≈øchal d' Humieres, only with 4 or 5000 Men to guard the Pa≈øs; but upon the approach of the Prince, finding him≈øelf to weak, he retired without di≈øputing it,
and ≈øo his Highne≈øs, with the Duke d ‚Ä¢ Villa Hermo≈øa, encamped near Valenciennes; but the French not being to be drawn out of their Retrenchments, i ‚Ä¢ was not thought expedient to attemp ‚Ä¢ the forcing them to a Battel; ≈øo tha ‚Ä¢ after may vigorous A≈ø≈øaults the Governour of Bouchain capitulated and ≈øurrendred the Place.

The Prince of Orange perceiving thi ‚Ä¢ Place lo≈øt, and that he could not forc ‚Ä¢ the French to a Battel without great di≈øadvantage, after ≈øome Councils held the Siege of ≈øome important Place wa ‚Ä¢ re≈øolved on, and accordingly his Highne≈øs laid Siege to Mae≈øtricht, having his Army encrea≈øed by the Arrival o ‚Ä¢ the O≈ønaburgh Troups, under the Command of that Duke, and the Siege wa ‚Ä¢ carried on with great Re≈øolution, an ‚Ä¢ nothing omitted that the highe≈øt Conduct and Valour was capable of performing; yet after a bloudy and ob≈øtinate Re≈øi≈øtence of the Be≈øieged, and th ‚Ä¢ Approach of the French Army, wit ‚Ä¢ a Re≈øolution to relieve them, his Highne≈øs thought it convenient to rai≈øe th ‚Ä¢ Siege and draw off, which he did i ‚Ä¢ good order: A brief Account of which you may ≈øee in the following Letter o ‚Ä¢

body.p:
THE Attack upon the Horne-Work, was not made as was intended the 25th. of Augu≈øt, but the day following before Noon, though without ≈øucce≈øs, and the Enemy being advanced with a very great Force to Tongres, it was unanimou≈øly concluded by the Generals, that they could not be hindred from putting a ≈øuccour into the Place on the ≈øide of the Wycke, and that for ≈øeveral difficulties that were fore≈øeen, it would be the be≈øt and ≈øafe≈øt to draw off the Troups from that ≈øide, and to put the whole Army into Battalia, without the lines, near Lenaken; which was accordingly done the next Morning, and we continued there till now. In the mean while all our Cannon, Ammunition, and part of the Provi≈øion, together with the ≈øick and wounded Men, where put into the lighte≈øt Ve≈ø≈øels, which could be≈øt pa≈øs, by rea≈øon of the extraordinary lowne≈øs of the Water: Having ≈øeen all our Cannon embarked, and ≈øent the Boats away, ≈øome Skirmi≈øhes happened, in which the Enemy was ≈øtill repul≈øed: It was to have been wi≈øhed that God would have been plea≈øed to have ble≈ø≈øed the extraordinary
Diligence, Vigilance, and Pains, which his Highne≈øs hath with the greate≈øt Care and Application taken, during this Siege, and ≈øo great danger to his Per≈øon, with better ≈øucce≈øs for the good of the State; but ≈øeeing it hath not been his Holy Will, I pray that he will plea≈øe, in other occa≈øions, to give the Arms of the State better ≈øucce≈øs.

div.p: Philipsburgh being this while be≈øieged by the Imperial Confederates, after a furious Battery, and many vigorous Attacks, the Governour perceiving a general A≈ø≈øault was intended, capitulated and ≈øurrendred it upon very advantageous Articles to Prince Herman of Baden, who commanded in chief at that Siege.

The Prince of Orange having drawn off his Forces from before Mae≈øtricht, and given the Mare≈øchal de Schomberg, who commanded the French Forces, all the opportunity imaginable to engage, which he declined, thinking it ≈øufficient that he had relieved the Town, he decamped from Lenaken, and marched to St. Tron, and there he ≈øent the Regiments that had ≈øu≈øtained the greate≈øt Lo≈øs in this Siege into Holland, to refre≈øh and recruit, and ≈øo with the re≈øt of the Cavalry and Infantry, took his
way towards Janche and Partui≈øe, his Excellency the Duke De Villa Hermo≈øa leading the Van, the Duke of O≈ønaburgh the main Battel, and his Highne≈øs the Rear-Guard, and although the French Army marched after him, yet they attempted nothing upon his Forces, however the Troups being allarm'd drew up in Battalia to expect them. And now the Winter-≈øea≈øon advancing, and the time of Action over, his Highne≈øs left the Army under the Command of Count Waldeck, and returned to Holland, where he was received with many Demon≈øtrations of joy, and proceeded to give the general A≈ø≈øembly of States an Account of that Summers Campaign, ≈øo much to their ≈øatisfaction, that the Pre≈øident in a mo≈øt ≈øolemn manner congratulated his ≈øafe Return, in his own, and in the names of all the States there a≈ø≈øembled: As likewi≈øe did the States of Holland by the Pen≈øioner Fagel, acknowledging all the Kindne≈øs and Gratitude imaginable, for the Care and Pains he had taken, and the Danger he had expo≈øed his Per≈øon to for the Honour and Service of the State.

In the year following, after a bloudy and doubtfull War, great were the expectations
of the People that a Peace would en≈øue; and the ≈øooner to bring it to pa≈øs, his Maje≈øty of Great Britain laboured by his Amba≈ø≈øadours and Envoys in the Court of the Princes, and engaged for an Accommodation, after the expence of ≈øo much Bloud and Trea≈øure as this vigorous War had exhau≈øted, but it went not on ≈øo pro≈øperou≈øly as was wi≈øhed by rea≈øon the French in the dead of the Winter were upon their March towards the Netherlands, which retarded the Negotiation, and by the fir≈øt of March, they had inve≈øted Valenciennes with between fifty and ≈øixty thou≈øand Men, under the Command of the Duke of Luxemburgh, and the Count of Montal; nor was it long before the King came to the Army with a great number of Voluntier Gentlemen. The Gari≈øon of that City con≈øi≈øted at that time of no more than 2000 Italians, Spaniards and Walloon Foot, and of about one thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Dragoons, Commanded by the Marque≈øs of Re≈øburg, ≈øo that before any con≈øiderable Force of the Confederates could take the Field, this City was formally be≈øieged, and the Sieg ‚Ä¢ carried on with extraordinary vigour as well by throwing Granadoes into it
as battering it with Cannon, running Trenches, Mining, &c. which ≈øo far facilitated the Enterprize by continually allarming and wearying out the be≈øieged, that the be≈øiegers made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the Counter≈øcarp and Horne-work with little difficulty, and turned the Guns they found there upon the City, which created ≈øuch a Con≈øternation, that the Governour finding the Soldiers and Inhabitants no longer willing to hazard them≈øelves again≈øt the encroaching Enemy, and not expecting any timely relief, he being at the ≈øame time wounded, and obliged to keep his Bed, the Place ≈øurrendred upon di≈øcretion; yet the French King commanded the Soldiers not to pillage it, and gave the Count of Risburg his Liberty; when hightened with this ≈øucce≈øs, he divided his Army, and at once be≈øieged Cambray, and St. Omers, the former of which, though well Gari≈øoned, he took without much difficulty, viz the Town, but the Ca≈øtle, whither the Soldiers retired to make their la≈øt Effort, held him in play much longer.

The Prince of Orange having by this time taken the Field, marched with the Army under his Command, to the Relief
of St. Omers, of which the French King had no ≈øooner notice, but he ≈øent away part of his Army to ≈øtrengthen that Leagure maintained by the Duke of Orleance: Nor was it un≈øea≈øonable, for the Prince having pa≈ø≈øed many difficult ways as al≈øo the River Pene, gave the Duke Battel, who had drawn off the greate≈øt part of his Army to oppo≈øe him; and though by the ill Di≈øcipline and Conduct of the left Wing, the di≈øadvantage of Ground and ≈øuperiour number of the French, after a long and doubtfull Fight, wherein he extremely hazarded his Per≈øon, and received two ≈øhots upon his Armour; he found him≈øelf obliged to retire with ≈øome Lo≈øs: Yet ≈øuch was the Action, that the Duke returned not to the Siege in eight days after, for fear of a ≈øecond Attack, nor till he was a≈ø≈øured his Highne≈øs had pa≈ø≈øed the Chanel of Gaunt: and then after a furious Battery, the Gari≈øon, who con≈øidered the encrea≈øe of his Army, and the little hopes they had of Relief, ≈øurrendred upon advantageous Articles; and about this time News came, that the Cittadel or Ca≈øtle of Cambray, after an ob≈øtinate re≈øi≈øtence, had ≈øurrendred upon very advantageous or honourable Conditions

This early ≈øucce≈øs of the French King rou≈øed the Confederates, who ha≈øtened their Armies from all Parts, and rendezvouzing near Alo≈øt, made a formidable Body, all but the Army the Duke of Lorain had brought into the Field, ≈øubmitting to the Command of the Prince; which ≈øo amazed the French King, that leaving the Mare≈øchal de Crequi, and the Duke of Luxemburgh, the former to attend the motion of the Duke of Lorain, and the latter to ob≈øerve the Prince, he left the Field and returned to Paris; whereupon his Highne≈øs marched towards Aeth, accompanied with the Duke De Villa Hermo≈øa, and the Duke of O≈ønaburgh, in order to di≈ølodge the French that were quartered under its Walls, or oblige them to Battel: but finding the Duke of Luxemburgh, who commanded there, advantageou≈øly encamped between two Rivers, and well fortified, ≈øhowing no inclination to leave his Po≈øt, he at that time contented him≈øelf with the making a flying Camp to prevent the French Parties ≈øtraggling abroad, and harra≈øing the nighbouring Countries, and with the reft of the Army ≈øet down before Charleroy, an important City, ≈øtrongly Gari≈øoned
by the French, which obliged the Duke of Luxemburgh, for the better ≈øtrengthening his Army, to draw the Soldiers out of divers Gari≈øons, and by that means formed a Body of 40000 Men, with which he fir≈øt endeavoured to cut off their Forage and Provi≈øion, coming from beyond the Sambre; and there the better to effect it, he ≈øtrongly entrenched him≈øelf, as knowing the cutting off the Forage mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity di≈øtre≈øs the Prince, which accordingly ≈øucceeded, and was one of the chief occa≈øions that induced his Highne≈øs to draw off the Army and march to Sombrief, and finding he could not oblige the French to a Battel without great di≈øadvantage, their chief aim being only to hinder his laying Siege to any Place of note, he drew nearer Bru≈ø≈øels, and there having given nece≈ø≈øary Orders, and left the Charge of the Armies to Count Waldeck, he pa≈ø≈øed from thence to the Hague, accompanied by ≈øundry Noble-men, as well Engli≈øh as others, and there gave the States an Account of his Conduct, with which they were very much ≈øatisfied, and returned his Highne≈øs their hearty Thanks for his weary Enterprizes, &c.

The French not appearing any ways inclinable to Action, or undertaking the Siege of any important Place, his Highne≈øs taking leave of the States, embarked for England, attended by the Earl of O≈ø≈øory and divers other Lords and Gentlemen, on the Yatches ≈øent for his Accommodation by His Maje≈øty of great Britain, King Charles II. and was attended by three Engli≈øh Men of War, and a Squadron the States ordered to wait upon him, Commanded by Admiral Evert≈øon; there was al≈øo in his Train the Count of Na≈ø≈øau, and Mr. Odyck, and proceeding with a pro≈øperous Gale, ≈øafely arrived at Harwich the 19th of October, 1677. where he was received by the Duke of Albemarle, and proceeding thence in the King's Coaches to Ip≈øwich, he was there very favourably received by his Maje≈øty, and a ≈øplendid Train of Nobility, as al≈øo by his Royal Highne≈øs, with all the Te≈øtimonies and Expre≈ø≈øions of real Joy and Affection, and on the 23d. they arrived at White-Hall, where his Royal Highne≈øs's Lodgings were prepared for his Reception, and ≈øoon after it was known to what intent his Highne≈øs had been invited over; nor did he on the 29th. of October fail, upon the Invitation
of the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of the City of London, to accompany His Maje≈øty, His Royal Highne≈øs, and the Court, to be a ≈øpectatour of the Cities magnificent annual Triumph, and was ≈øplendidly entertained to his high ≈øatisfaction. Now the King having cho≈øen his Highne≈øs from among≈øt the Princes of Europe as the fitte≈øt Match for his illu≈øtrious Neece, the Prince≈øs Mary, for which intent he was invited to Court, he on the fir≈øt of November declared his Intention in Council, with which the Lords were extremely ≈øatisfied, as well in the Merits of his Highne≈øs, as the ≈øecurity of the Prote≈øtant Religion, by ≈øo agreeable a Match, and the better for the con≈øervation of a Peace with the united Provinces; whereupon the Council, to te≈øtifie a farther mark of the contentment they received, went in a body to Complement and Congratulate the Prince≈øs, and then the Prince upon this happy occa≈øion, as did afterwards the re≈øt of the Nobility of the Kingdom, and others, a general ≈øatisfaction being every where expre≈ø≈øed; ≈øo that his Highne≈øs ≈øent an Expre≈øs to the States General, to acquaint them with what was intended; the Summe of which was:

That in con≈øideration they had by their earne≈øt Wi≈øhes to him declared how much they de≈øired to ≈øee him Married, after he had well weighed the Rea≈øons that had induced him to it, in Conformity to their De≈øires, and the Tranquillity of their State, he conceived he could not doe better than to addre≈øs him≈øelf to the Prince≈øs Mary, elde≈øt Daughter to the Duke of York, that he had made his Reque≈øt to have her in Marriage, both of the King and the Duke, who had conde≈øcended to his Propo≈øals and therefore he thought it requi≈øite to give their Lord≈øhips notice of it, expecting in return their ≈øpeedy Approbation, that he might the ≈øooner ha≈øten again to their Service.

Upon this notice of his Highne≈øs's Intentions, the States a≈ø≈øembled to con≈øider the weighty Rea≈øons that induced him to make ≈øo happy a choice in placing his Affections on the mo≈øt illu≈øtrious Prince≈øs in Europe, and with much Joy & Gratulation approved them, te≈øtifying by a publick Edict, the ≈øatisfaction they conceived, and declaring the e≈øteem of ≈øo great an Alliance, made a re≈øolution to ob≈øerve it to the utmo≈øt of their power, and accordingly ≈øent their Approbation
to his Highne≈øs on the 4th. of November, old Style, on which day the happy Marriage was ≈øolemnized, the Ceremonies performed by the Bi≈øhop of London, and the King gave the Prince≈øs: Nor did the News appear in publick but with the greate≈øt Demon≈øtrations of Joy imaginable, the Bells every where rang, and Bon-fires flam'd in the ≈øtreets, and an univer≈øal con≈øent ≈øpread over the Kingdom, and Congratulatory Poems were made by the be≈øt hands upon the occa≈øion. But whil≈øt every one was Reveling in Joy and Contentment, the Prince had his thoughts employed upon the important Bu≈øine≈øs of the State, and having received the farther Complements and Congratulations of the Nobles and Gentry, he on the 29th. took his leave of the Court, together with his fair Prince≈øs, and with a Train of Noble-men and Ladies took his way to embark for Holland, whither he was attended by ≈øeveral Men of War, and having a pro≈øperous Pa≈ø≈øage landed at Ter-heyde, and from thence pa≈ø≈øed to Houn≈øleyrdyke, where for ≈øome time their Highne≈ø≈øes continued, and received private Vi≈øits till the Magnificence that was to attend their publick Entry into the Hague was prepared; where upon
their Ingre≈øs the Bridge was crowned with Garlands of Triumph, and under them written,
div.q: ∆≤xori & Batavis vivat Na≈ø≈øovius Hector Auriaco & Patriae vivat Britanica Princeps.
div.p: Here they found likewi≈øe the twelve Companies of Burghers drawn up in Arms, and the People every where expre≈ø≈øing their ≈øatisfaction with loud and joyfull Acclamations; and upon pa≈ø≈øing the Bridge 24 Virgins met them, ≈øinging Songs prepared for the occa≈øion, and ≈øtrewing the way with fragrant Herbs on each ≈øide the Coach wherein their Highne≈ø≈øes were; and arriving at the Town-hou≈øe, they found a Triumphal Arch erected, through which they pa≈ø≈øed; this Arch was beautified and adorned with a Sylvian Scene, and on the top a Hieroglyphick of Amity, by the cla≈øping of two hands, and a Motto, viz.
div.q: Auriaci his Thalamis, Bataevis dos Regia pax e≈øt.
div.p:
Then cro≈ø≈øing the Market-place into the High-≈øtreet, they found another Arch erected, with this Motto, viz. Ingredere Au≈øpicius Batavis Felicibus Aulam.
and in the mean time the Cannon was fired from all parts, and the Burghers gave ≈øeveral Volleys; at Night the whole Country was enlightened with Bon-fires, and Fire-works of ≈øundry kinds and forms, and ≈øo with great joy and ≈øatisfaction pa≈ø≈øed the re≈øt of the Winter, little Action happening abroad in that ≈øea≈øon; yet the French King made early preparations again≈øt the Spring, which obliged his Maje≈øty of Great Britain, as he had before de≈øigned, to labour to compo≈øe the unhappy differences that had occa≈øioned the expence of ≈øo much Bloud and Trea≈øure; and in order to it he ≈øent the Earl of Fever≈øham to the French King, with In≈øtructions to negotiate a Peace between that King and the Confederates; the purport of his Commi≈ø≈øion was to propo≈øe, That the City of Charleroy, Aeith, Courtray, Tournay, Conde, Oudenard, Valenciennes, and St. Guilain ≈øhould be re≈øtored to the Spaniards, in con≈øideration of which, the French King ≈øhould keep La Frenche Conte intire; but this not ≈øucceeding, His Maje≈øty of Great Britain di≈øpatched a Commi≈ø≈øion, fully impowring the Lord Hide his Amba≈ø≈øadour at the Hague, to make Alliance with the States General, mutually
to ≈øtand by and defend each other, till they could oblige the French King to Rea≈øon; the Engli≈øh Parliament at the ≈øame time declaring ≈øtrongly for it, and offering the King con≈øiderable Summes of Mony to carry on the projected De≈øign again≈øt the Di≈øturber of Chri≈øtendom.

The Alliance was to be carried on in order to the recovering a ≈øatisfaction by ≈øuch means as ≈øhould be thought mo≈øt expedient and be≈øt agreeable; and indeed for a time it was vigorou≈øly maintained, the Parliament of England pre≈ø≈øing it with a more than ordinary Ardour, and the King ≈øent the Lord Montague his Amba≈ø≈øadour to France, once more to pre≈øs that King to a Compliance, making at the ≈øame time new Levies of Hor≈øe and Foot: However the French King rejecting the Propo≈øitions, was not idle, but made great preparations for War; whereupon the King of Great Britain recalled his Forces that were in the French Service, who were ≈øent home without their Arrears. But whil≈øt the Confederates were agreeing about their Quota's or Levies, the French early in the Spring be≈øieged Gaunt, which being taken, by rea≈øon of the in≈øufficiency of
the Gari≈øon to maintain a place of that va≈øt Circuit, they ≈øate down before Ypre, which after a re≈øolute defence ≈øurrendred.

The≈øe Places thus lo≈øt for want of ≈øuccour, made the Confederates draw out from all Parts, the Prince of Orange being the fir≈øt that took the Field, and the Duke of Monmouth arrived at Bruges with about 3000 Engli≈øh Hor≈øe and Foot; but the French King having done as much as he thought convenient at that time, putting the greater part of his numerous Armies into Gari≈øons to refre≈øh them, he retired to Paris; but hearing the League again≈øt him continually ≈øtrengthened by new Alliances, and a Prohibition of the growth of his Kingdom, he thought it no longer convenient to delay, but formed him≈øelf a Project of Accommodation, to this purpo≈øe, viz.

list.item: That the Prince and Bi≈øhop of Stra≈øburgh ≈øhould be entirely re≈øtored to all his Territories, Honours, Prerogatives and Goods, and Prince William of Fur≈øtemburgh, his Brother be ≈øet at Liberty.

That in relation to the Emperour he would ≈øtand to his Declarations, in≈øi≈øting upon the
Treaties of We≈øtphalia, offering to re≈øtore Philipsburgh or Friburgh.

That to the King of Spain he would re≈øtore Charleroy, Aeith, Courtray, Gaunt, Oudenard, and St. Guilain, together with Cha≈øtlerains and all their Dependencies, but re≈øerve to him≈øelf Conde, Bouchain, Air, Cambray, Valenciennes, and Saint Omers, with all their Ca≈øtles and Dependencies, with La Frenche Conte entire.
That he would re≈øtore Charlemont or Dinant to the Spaniard with the Emperour and Bi≈øhop of Liege's con≈øent.

That the Confines between Spain & the Low Countrys from the Sea ≈øhould be the Meu≈øe, Newport, Courtray, Aeith, Dixmund, Mons, Oudenard, Namur, and Charleroy, and tho≈øe Bounds to be a≈ø≈øured by tho≈øe Places.
That moreover to the States General he would re≈øtore Mae≈øtricht, and allow the Commerce, as formerly granted.

That he would re≈øtore to the Duke of Lorain, according to the Pyrenean Treaty, or ≈øurrender to him, excepting Nancy, all his Territories, and in lieit of that City he would give him Toul, thereby only re≈øerving to him≈øelf a free pa≈ø≈øage into Al≈øatia. And farther demanded ≈øatisfaction for his Allies.

div.p:
The propo≈øals were not generally liked, yet after many Difficulties and Refu≈øals,
the Treaty was at length ≈øigned by the Plenipotentiaries of France and Holland, on the 11th. of Augu≈øt, 1678. yet the delays of the French King proved extremely prejudicial to his Affairs, e≈øpecially in le≈ø≈øening the Reputation his Arms had gained; for whil≈øt the Treaty held with indifferency, and wavered without any certainty of coming to a conclu≈øion, the Prince of Orange having joyned the Confederate Forces, they called a Council of War, in which it was concluded that ≈øeeing Mons, a City of the Province of Hainault, had been a long time Blocked up by the French, and that the Duke of Luxemburgh was on his March with the Army under his Command, to prevent any Succours being put into the City, that it was convenient to intercept him, and with this Re≈øolution the Prince and the Confederate Army ≈øet forward about the beginning of Augu≈øt, and was joyned in his March by ≈øix thou≈øand Mun≈øterians and Brandenburghers, under the Command of General Spaen. The French upon notice of his Approach removed from Soignes, where they had lain for ≈øome time encamped, where the next day the Prince decamped with the Confederate
Army, and from thence marched toward Rockle≈øs, advancing the left Wing as far as the Abby of St. Dennis, that Place being the Duke of Luxemburgh's chief Quarters, facing with his Right Wing Ca≈øteau, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed likewi≈øe by the French; and although the Pa≈ø≈øes were extreme difficult, which rendred the French more ≈øecure, yet the Army being embatteled, his Highne≈øs commanded a Party to drive the French from a Hillock they had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, which was performed with little difficulty; and then he cau≈øed the great Guns to play upon the Enemy that had po≈øted them≈øelves near the Cloi≈øter, adjacent to the Town; and though they ≈øtrove to defend it with their Cannon, yet after a con≈øiderable Battery, a Party of Dragoons advanced, and after a ≈øharp di≈øpute drove them thence, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Place, when in the mean time Adjutant General Collyer, ≈øeconded by General Delwick, pa≈ø≈øed the Defiles, or narrow dirty Lanes, with admirable courage, contrary to the expectation of the French, and drove them, after a ≈øtrenuous re≈øi≈øtence, into their own Lines; when the Prince, accompanied by the Duke of Monmouth, who fought by his
≈øide that day, fell in with great re≈øolution and bravery, encouraging by words and actions the Regiments that were advanced, and ≈øignallizing his Valour above Report, which ≈øo animated the Regiments of the left Wing that they followed each other till the Evening charging with great re≈øolution; and Count Horn bending the Cannon under his Charge again≈øt the Battalions of French that were drawn up in the Valley, it greatly endamaged them by battering their Ranks.

The Fight being thus begun, was carried on and maintained with much re≈øolution and bravery, the Prince, forcing his Pa≈ø≈øage to Ca≈øteau, which had been Attacked by the Spaniards in the right Wing, where his Regiments of Foot-Guards had the Van-Guard under the Command of Count Solms, and was ≈øeconded by the Regiments of Hol≈øtein, Roques, Sereres, and they ≈øupported by the Engli≈øh, who through the natural aver≈øion they had to the French, charged with ≈øuch fury, that the ob≈øtinate re≈øi≈øtence the Enemy made could not ≈øu≈øtain their impetuo≈øity; for after five hours di≈øpute the French were driven from their Po≈øt by the Regiments of
Guards, who pur≈øued them to the River Haines, on the other ≈øide of Ca≈øteau: And in this Battel it was that the renowned Earl of O≈ø≈øory, who commanded the Engli≈øh, ≈øignalized his Valour; and indeed the whole ≈øtre≈øs of the Battel lay upon the Infantry, the Cavalry not being very ≈øerviceable in a Place of ≈øuch narrow acce≈øs, and ≈øo full of precipices. Night putting an end to the Slaughter, the Duke of Luxemburgh finding his lo≈øs great, and that he was no longer capable of making good his Po≈øt, drew off, under the favour of the darkne≈øs of the Night, in much Silence and Confu≈øion, and took a new Po≈øt nearer Mons, covering his Army with a Wood on the one ≈øide, and on the other it was ≈øecured by a River, leaving behind him mo≈øt of the wounded Men, with many Tents, and much Baggage and Ammunition.

The Prince upon this advantage, would have pur≈øued the French to have given them a total Defeat, and free the Town of Mons from the apprehen≈øion of Danger: But whil≈øt he was preparing to make a ≈øecond Attack, an Expre≈øs was ≈øent him, that the Treaty was ≈øigned between the States and the French King; however, they congratulated his Highne≈øs
upon this Succe≈øs, in an extraordinary manner, intreating him to be more ≈øparing of their ≈øafety than to hazard him≈øelf in the mid≈øt of danger; and the better to demon≈øtrate at how dear a rate they e≈øteemed his pre≈øervation, they ≈øent to Mr. Owerkirks (a Per≈øon who had enterpo≈øed him≈øelf between the Prince and a French Captain, that in the heat of the Fight was in a full Carier to charge him at adi≈øadvantage) a Sword, who≈øe Hilt was of Ma≈ø≈øy Gold, a pair of Pi≈øtols inlay'd with Gold and a pair of golden Hor≈øe-buckles.

Upon the News that the Treaty was ≈øigned, a Ce≈ø≈øation of Arms en≈øued, and upon the Duke of Luxemburgh's drawing off to the Country between the Mu≈øe and Sambre, the Prince marched to E≈øcou≈øines, upon the Road to Nivelle, and there being no farther Bu≈øine≈øs in relation to warlike Action, he came to the Hague, where he was received by the People, with the highe≈øt demon≈øtration of Joy and Acclamation; and this la≈øt ≈øucce≈øs no doubt ha≈øtened the Conclu≈øion of the Treaty between France and Spain, which was agreed on the 17th. of November following, yet it la≈øted not long, before the French King upon the claiming ≈øeveral places in the Spani≈øh
Netherlands as Dependencies, blocked up Luxemburgh, which obliged the King of Great Britain, Guarrantee of the Peace, to interpo≈øe his Authority, as likewi≈øe did the States, by way of Mediation; but the French King would not hearken to the quitting the claim he had laid, unle≈øs the City of Luxemburgh might be put into his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, with all its Dependencies, three Leagues round it; which being long debated, and the time the French King gave to come to a Re≈øolve being expired, without concluding any thing of that Affair, the Mare≈øchal d' Humieres fell into the Spani≈øh Provinces with a numerous Army, and put them under Contribution, making great ≈øpoil, and ravage in many places; and not ≈øo contented, but upon the Prince of Chimai's (Governour of Luxemburgh) acting ≈øome Ho≈øtilities in their Territories, the Mare≈øchal laid Siege to, and took Courtray, burning many places of le≈ø≈øer note, con≈øtraining others to pay a Ran≈øome for ≈øaving them≈øelves from Fire; and in conclu≈øion, the Mare≈øchal d' Crequi came before Luxemburgh with an Army of 30000 Men, and ca≈øt a great number of Bombs into that City, which burnt and demoli≈øhed about
Five hundred Hou≈øes, and ≈øo retired to put his Army into Winter Quarters; and in the mean while the Negotiation continued between the Arbritours to ≈øettle the Differences between the two Crowns; nor did they ≈øpare any Diligence to create a good under≈øtanding, by propo≈øing Equivalents; but the Spaniards at that time, were ≈øo much aver≈øe, that the Mediatours began to give over the hopes they had conceived of accommodating Matters in di≈øpute; nay the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour proceeded ≈øo far, as to pre≈øs the King of Great Britain to ≈øend over Forces to the A≈ø≈øi≈øtence of his Ma≈øter; but the King told him, That the urgency of his Affairs at home could not admit of ≈øending Forces abroad, but that he was willing to doe the King of Spain all the good Offices that lay in him, &c. as al≈øo to u≈øe his utmo≈øt Endeavours for the Peace and Repo≈øe of Europe. But not ≈øatisfied with this An≈øwer, they again applyed them≈øelves to the States. General, but they being not willing to enter into any new Engagement of War with France, the Amba≈ø≈øadours could not per≈øuade them to make new Levies, or to ≈øend any Forces to the A≈ø≈øi≈øtence of His Catholick Maje≈øty; nor could the Emperour
give any a≈ø≈øi≈øtence, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtorm that threatened him at that time in Hungary; ≈øo that indeed the whole State of Europe being unwilling, or not in a condition to enter into a new War, it was greatly hoped that this would oblige tho≈øe that ≈øtood out to a compliance: And the better to perfect an Alliance, a general Congre≈øs was held at the Hague, where it was thought ≈øomewhat rea≈øonable, that the True of Twenty years which the French King had offered ≈øhould be accepted, including the Allies on all parts; which coming to a Re≈øolve, and the Articles of Treaty agreed, among≈øt other things, it was thought fit that the French King ≈øhould re≈øtore to the King of Spain, Dixmuyden, and Courtray, with their Dependencies, having liberty to demoli≈øh the Fortifications; as likewi≈øe the other Places taken by force ≈øince the 30th. of Augu≈øt, 1683. and that in con≈øideration thereof, the King of Spain ≈øhould Surrender to him Beaumont, Luxemburgh, Chimai and Bovines, with all their Dependencies; and to this purpo≈øe the Articles between the two Crowns were concluded on at Ratisbon. And now the French King being at lei≈øure, began to grow exceeding trouble≈øome
to his Prote≈øtant Subjects, having, during the former Tran≈øactions, put a very ≈øen≈øible Affront upon his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange; for whil≈øt the Differences la≈øted between the French & the Spaniards, they extremely wa≈øted his Patrimony in Brabant, Burgundy, and Luxemburgh, where the Prince of I≈øenguyn, ≈øupported by the French Intere≈øt and Arms, had ≈øeized upon his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Warne≈ø≈øon, De≈øburgh, Vianden, St. ∆≤ith, Budgenback, &c. yet out of a genero≈øity to his Country, in preferring their Peace and Tranquillity before his own intere≈øt, he forbore at that time to put in for Reparation; nor could the Violences the French King unju≈øtly offered in entring upon his Principality of Orange be le≈øs re≈øented, by which Act he ≈øeemed to have this farther de≈øign, viz. To hinder the Prote≈øtant Religion from flouri≈øhing there; for upon the Per≈øecution he rai≈øed in all parts of his own Territories, many of the Prote≈øtants ≈øent their Children to this Sovereign Principality to be Educated in Learning; but this greatly di≈øplea≈øing him, he ≈øent his Orders to Mon≈øieur Moran Super-intendent of Provence, to March a Body of 2000 Men thither, under the Command of his Lieutenant-General
in Languedock, to command the Magi≈øtrates of the Principality of Orange to ≈øend away all the Children to their Parents, and not for the future to receive any more into their Schools or Academies. To this unju≈øt and unrea≈øonable Demand they found them≈øelves con≈øtrained to con≈øent, promi≈øing to give notice to the Parents of the Children, that they might ≈øend for them home, hoping by this means they had given the King ≈øatisfaction: But what can ≈øatisfie an ambitious & ≈øpightfull Mind? for although this gave the Citizens hope they were in Peace, yet it proved not ≈øo, for ≈øoon after Orders came to throw down the Walls of the City, and the French Dragoons Quartering upon the Inhabitants, committed many Indecencies and Di≈øorders, compelling the People to Work in ruining their own Fortifications, which being undermined, were blown up.

This News no ≈øooner came to his Highne≈øs's Council, but they complained of it to the States-General, as a breach of the la≈øt Peace, urging, that Reparation might be required for ≈øuch unju≈øt Proceedings again≈øt the Subjects of his Highne≈øs, in the mid≈øt of a general
Peace: Nor were the States wanting in Writing to the King, and letting him know their Re≈øentments for ≈øo great an Injury, contrary to the Treaty of Nimeguen, pre≈ø≈øing him for Reparation of the damage his Highne≈øs had, contrary to Articles, ≈øu≈øtained in the Violence done to his Subjects: But they could get no other An≈øwer from the French Court, but that as for the Money extorted from the Inhabitants, tho≈øe that extorted it had no Order for it, and he had commanded Re≈øtitution to be made, and upon the Peoples ≈øubmitting to his Plea≈øure, he had withdrawn his Forces, and re≈øtored the Inhabitants their Commerce according to their De≈øires; but as for the re≈øt, he alledged he had rea≈øon for what he did. This An≈øwer, though it was neither generous, nor plea≈øing, was all that could be got at that time, and ≈øo the matter continues to a more favourable opportunity.

The Face of Peace now appearing among≈øt the Chri≈øtian Princes, and Hungary, being the greate≈øt Scene of War, the States thought of Disbanding their ≈øupernumerary Forces, and in order thereto advi≈øed with his Highne≈øs, who a≈ø≈øured them that there was no Per≈øon
more de≈øirous than him≈øelf to ea≈øe the People of their Contributions and Taxes; but in con≈øideration things were ≈øcarcely ≈øettled, and that the nighbouring Countries had not yet Disbanded, but were in Arms, he thought it the ≈øafe≈øt way to continue them till they might be a≈ø≈øuredly free from the fear or ≈øu≈øpicion of any ≈øini≈øter event, &c. And according to this prudent and grave Coun≈øel they were continued, it being re≈øolved by the States-General, That the Extraordinary Forces ≈øhould be kept up to a farther time. And now his Highne≈øs being more at lei≈øure, and de≈øirous to promote the good of his Country, betook him≈øelf to the reforming the Government of ∆≤ treicht, in which, during the Series of ≈øo tedious a War, ≈øome Di≈øorders and Irregularities had happened; which he redre≈ø≈øed by prudently altering ≈øuch of the Magi≈øtracy as were looked upon unfit Per≈øons to manage the Government, and put ≈øuch into their places as he found better capable of managing ≈øo weighty a Tru≈øt; ≈øtriving to promote and advance the welfare of the People at no ≈ømall expence of Pains and Trea≈øure, contrary to the Methods of the French King, who was then Dragooning
his Subjects of the Prote≈øtant Religion, and u≈øing all manner of ways to ruine them by Tortures, Confi≈øcations, and Impri≈øonments, and many ≈øuch unchri≈øtian-like Proceedings.

His Highne≈øs having in good order landed the greate≈øt part of the Hor≈øe and Foot, and given Directions for the ≈øpeedy landing the re≈øt, and the Cannon to be un-≈øhipped, for the more conveniency at Top≈øham, he marched towards the City of Exeter, with the general Approbation, Shouts, and Applau≈øe of the People, who flocked from all parts to welcome him; and divers Gentlemen of tho≈øe parts came to wait upon him, and tender their ≈øervice upon his approach, the Bi≈øhop retired, and the Gates were clo≈øed, by Order of the Mayor, but without baracadoing or fa≈øtening, ≈øo that being ≈øoon opened, an advanc'd party enter'd, and was joyfully received by the Inhabitants, a great many of them having before their coming,
