The Prince continuing ≈øtill in the City of Exeter, gave nece≈ø≈øary Orders for the Settlement of the Revenue of
tho≈øe Parts, ari≈øing by Exci≈øe, and other Duties, where the King's Officers were at that time remi≈øs in their Attendence, ≈øome of them being Roman Catholicks, and fled, he appointed the Lord Wilt≈øhire, Mr. Herbert, and Mr. Row, Commi≈ø≈øioners, for the more prudent Management, and ≈øent out Parties to purcha≈øe Hor≈øes for their Service; His Highne≈øs recreating him≈øelf at times, by taking a view of the Country, but his Army almo≈øt hourly increa≈øing, he commanded detached Parties to advance, and po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of convenient Po≈øts; and in the mean time we had News that the Lord Delamere came to Manche≈øter with a ≈øtrong Party, and there declared for His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, and made a Speech to his Tenents, and others, de≈øiring them to meet him the next day at Bodon Downs, the intended Place of Rendezvouz; where accordingly he found a great appearance, who willingly ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to be di≈øpo≈øed under his Command: But the Lord Lovelace being on his way to join with the Prince, with a Party of Hor≈øe, was ≈øurprized in his Inn at Cirence≈øter by the Militia; and (after a ≈øtout re≈øi≈øtence, in which
the Major that commanded, together with his Son, and ≈øome others, were killed,) his Lord≈øhip was taken Pri≈øoner, and afterward carried to Glouce≈øter, but was there re≈øcued by a Party of the Prince's Hor≈øe.

The King upon notice that his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange had left Exeter, and was advancing with his own and the additional Forces that were come in, cau≈øed the Train of Artillery to be drawn out of the Tower, being before prepared on Carriages fit to March; and pa≈ø≈øing towards Salisbury, he prepared his Equipage to be at the Head of his Army, which was ordered to draw together about Salisbury, and accordingly ≈øetting out from White-Hall with no great Attendence, he arrived there the 19th. of November, about Four in the Evening, and was met by the Duke of Berwick, the Earl of Fever≈øbam, and other Commanders, on Hor≈øe-back, a Mile from the Gates of the City, where he was attended by the Mayor and Aldermen, in their Formalities, to the Bi≈øhop's Palace, appointed for his Lodgings; and there perceiving an almo≈øt general falling off of the Nobility and Gentry, as well as the Forces under his Pay, and that divers
Lords were up in the North, he i≈ø≈øued out a Proclamation, bearing Date the 20th. of November, offering a Pardon to all his Subjects that had taken up Arms under the Prince, if they returned in Twenty Days, and rendered them≈øelves to the Officers Military and Civil, &c.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things happened, a Party of the Prince's Men being abroad, and advancing beyond their Strengths, were pur≈øued and charged by Coll. Sarsfield, with 70 Hor≈øe, and 30 Dragoons and Granadiers; and overtaking them at Wincanton, they po≈øted them≈øelves behind the Hedges; upon which the Dragoons and Granadiers were obliged to di≈ømount, and march up to the Hedges, ≈øo that they began to Fire very briskly on both ≈øides, and ≈øeveral were killed and wounded; but Collonel Sarsfield getting into the Field with his Hor≈øe, and Charging them in the Rear, they were mo≈øt of them killed and taken Pri≈øoners. Among≈øt the Slain was one Cambell, a Lieutenant, who commanded them; and on the King's Party four were killed, and Cornet Web mortally wounded.

This ≈ølender Succe≈øs was clouded, upon Notice that the Earl of Bath had Seized upon Plymouth, and made the Earl of Huntington, the Governour thereof, Pri≈øoner; the whole Gari≈øon declaring for His Highne≈øs, upon reading his Declarations; the Fleet likewi≈øe began to grow cold, and many of the Commanders began to declare for the Prince; ≈øo that the King not thinking it convenient to hazard a Battel with an Army he could no ways en≈øure to his Intere≈øt, upon the near Approaches of the Prince's Forces, (with whom were now a great part of the Nobility) he ha≈øtily left Salisbury, drawing off tho≈øe Forces he had there, and remanding the Train of Artillery returned to White-Hall, where he arrived on the 26th. of November, in the Evening, and appointed Collonel Beville Skelton Lieutenant of the Tower, in in the Place of Sir Edward Hales; and according to what had been de≈øired by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, in their Petition, gave Order to the Lord Chancellour, for I≈ø≈øuing out Writs for the Summoning a Parliament to ≈øit the 15th. day of the en≈øuing January, and Commi≈ø≈øioners were nominated to
treat with the Prince: A Proclamation was likewi≈øe publi≈øh'd to give timely notice to tho≈øe that were Electors, or would ≈øtand for Candidates: The Bi≈øhop of Exeter was likewi≈øe nominated Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of the long vacant See of York, and did Homage to the King the day after the Ceremonies of his Tran≈ølation from the See of Exeter to the Archiepi≈øcopal See of York; which were performed at Lambeth, by his Grace the Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Bi≈øhops of St. A≈øaph, Ely, Roche≈øter, and Peterborough.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things were doing, News came that the Lords in the North had ≈øeized upon York, and made the Governour Pri≈øoner, declaring for the Prince of Orange, and di≈øarming all Papi≈øts of note, their Number and Power daily increa≈øing; ≈øo that the Lord Mollenax, who was up with a party for the King in tho≈øe Parts, found him≈øelf in no condition to make any head; but ≈øoon after was de≈øerted by mo≈øt of his Followers; and the ≈øtrong Gari≈øon of Hull was ≈øecured to the Intere≈øt of His Highne≈øs, by the Deputy Governour, and by the A≈ø≈øi≈øtence of the Soldiers of
his Party, the Towns-men , and ≈øome Sea-men that were in the Port; the ≈øecuring it, according to the Relation, being on this manner.

On the 3d. of December, about 9 of the Clock, the Guards being ≈øet, and the Tat-too over , the Deputy-Governour, as it was his place, was preparing to go the Rounds, but the Lord Langdale, the Governour, told him he had appointed the Lord Montgomery, and Major Fountain, to ≈øupply that Duty for the Night; whereupon ≈øome Words pa≈ø≈øing, the Deputy Governour made his Party, and drawing up the Soldiers in Battalia, ≈øiezed the Guards, and made the Lord Langdale, the Lord Montgomery, and others, Pri≈øoners; and at break of day a Party was ≈øent over the Bridge, to ≈øeize the Ca≈øtle, and Block-Hou≈øes, with the new Citadel; ≈øo that the Inhabitants and Sea-men concurring with the Soldiers, that ≈øtrong Place was entirely ≈øecured, and the Ma≈øs-Hou≈øe demoli≈øhed with great joy, and ringing of Bells, and the Prince's Colours were placed upon the high Church; the Papi≈øts that had come thither for ≈øhelter were turned out, and the Governour di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and guarded a
part of the way to his Hou≈øe, to prevent the danger that threatened him from the Mobile, who began to be very in≈øolent. Divers other places declared likewi≈øe for the Prince; and the Duke of Beaufort, who had Commanded the County Militia, perceiving he could not in that kind advantage the King's Affairs, which were now grown de≈øperate, betook him≈øelf to his Retirement; ≈øo that the Militia found them≈øelves disbanded.

The Noblemen who were ≈øent to treat with his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, about accommodating the affairs of the Kingdom, not being able to effect in all points what the King de≈øired, the Infant, which had been ≈øent to Port≈ømouth, either as ≈øuppo≈øed the ≈øecure≈øt place, or to pa≈øs the Seas, was ≈øent for back in great ha≈øte; and the Prie≈øts began to ≈øhift for them≈øelves, Father Petre was mi≈ø≈øing, with divers others, who it is ≈øuppo≈øed, perceiving the de≈øperatene≈øs of their condition, made an early e≈øcape; and ≈øeveral Councils were held, mo≈øt of them privately in the King's Clo≈øet, to advi≈øe what was to he done in the Juncture of affairs; when on the 9th. of December,
in the Evening, News came that greatly allarm'd the Court, and put it for the mo≈øt part in a hurry and con≈øternation, viz. That the Prince's Forces had made their way through Reading, and gained the Pa≈øs of Twyford-bridge, without any con≈øiderable re≈øi≈øtence: And thus we find the account of this Action.

About 1500 Hor≈øe, and 3 Troups of Iri≈øh Dragoons being quartered, or po≈øted in the Town of Reading, were put into a Con≈øternation upon the Report, that a ≈øtrong advanced Party of the Prince's Army were on their march to beat up their Quarters; ≈øo that after ≈øome Con≈øultation of the Officers, it was concluded they ≈øhould draw off to Twyford-Bridge, and there make good their Po≈øt, which accordingly they did; but the Scouts that were ≈øent abroad to di≈øcover, coming in, and giving them an account that the Roads were clear, the Commander in chief commanded that Claverhou≈øe Regiment of Scotch Hor≈øe, and the Iri≈øh Dragoons, ≈øhould march back, and repo≈ø≈øe≈øs the Town of Reading, which they did on the Eighth of December at Night, with Orders to be in readine≈øs, and upon their Guards
to prevent ≈øurprize; ≈øo that mo≈øt of them kept on Hor≈øe-back, ≈øome in the Market-place, and others at the Po≈øts a≈ø≈øigned them; but there being yet no news of the advanc'd Party, they were commanded by their Officers to alight, and refre≈øh them≈øelves and their Hor≈øes; when at ten of the Clock in the Morning, the Trumpet ≈øounded to Hor≈øe, the Prince's Forces being at the Town's end, almo≈øt before they were di≈øcovered, whereupon a ≈øharp di≈øpute en≈øued, with brisk Firing on both Parties; the Iri≈øh Dragoons bearing the brunt of the Encounter, though the Scotch Hor≈øe in ≈ømall detatched Bodies made ≈øome Firings; but they were overpowered, driven out of the Town, and obliged to retreat to Twyford-Bridge; and in conclu≈øion, many of the King's Party De≈øerted, and the re≈øt were con≈øtrained to quit the Pa≈øs, and make the be≈øt of their Retreat. In this Skirmi≈øh we cannot learn that above Thirty were killed, and ≈øeveral wounded. But now the King having no con≈øiderable Forces, e≈øpecially none capable of making Head again≈øt a prevailing Army; the Queen, who had been at Wind for the day before, to fetch the
Infant, taking her ≈øolemn leave of the King, cro≈ø≈øed the Thames on the Tenth of December, about Three in the Morning, where her Coaches waited for her; and ≈øo with the Child, and a ≈ølender Attendence, made for Dover, or ≈øome Port near it, and there took Shipping for France, where ≈øhe ≈øoon after landed, and had a place of Re≈øidence appointed her by the French King.

The Queen having left White-Hall, as al≈øo a great many of the Courtiers, the King the ≈øame Evening called an extraordinary Council; and ≈øent for the Lord Mayor of London, and the Sheriffs; who waiting upon His Maje≈øty, were, among≈øt other things, charged to have a Care of the City, and keep it in Peace and Quietne≈øs, as much as in them lay, and then were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed: However, the Council held a long Debate, and a meeting was appointed the, the next Morning; but, contrary to the Expectation of almo≈øt the whole Kingdom, the King, about Three a Clock in the Night, took Barge at the Privy Stairs, with a ≈ømall Equipage; and went down the River on his Departure, without giving notice to any of the Officers of his Hou≈øhold, who were then in

The King's Departure, was no ≈øooner ≈øpread abroad, but the Lords Spiritual and Temporal that were about Town a≈ø≈øembled; and finding White-Hall full of Con≈øternation, after ≈øome Debates, they gave order for the di≈ømi≈ø≈øing Popi≈øh Officers and Soldiers; and giving Directions for the keeping of that Palace from Pillage or Spoil, which in that Confu≈øion might have happened, they adjourned immediately to the Guild Hall of the City of London, where, by their Order, the Lord Mayor had ≈øummoned the Court of Aldermen, and thither they ≈øent for Collonel Bevil Skelton, Lieutenant of the Tower; and ordered him, to re≈øign up that important Citadel to the Lord Lucas, in tru≈øt of the City, till other Mea≈øures could be taken; and proceeded to approve and ≈øign the following Declaration, viz.

q.p:
We doubt not, but the World believes, that in this great and dangerous Conjuncture We are Heartily and Zealou≈øly concerned for the Prote≈øtant Religion, the Laws of the Land, and the Liberties and Properties of the Subject; and we did rea≈øonably hope, that the King having I≈ø≈øued out his Proclamation and Writs for a Free
Parliament, We might have re≈øted ≈øecure under the Expectation of that Meeting; but His Maje≈øty having withdrawn him≈øelf, and as we apprehend, in order to his Departure out of the Kingdom, by the pernicious Coun≈øels of Per≈øon, ill-affected to our Nation, and Religion, We cannot, without being wanting to our Duty, be ≈øilent under the Calamities wherein the Popi≈øh Coun≈øels, which ≈øo long prevailed, have mi≈øerably involved us: We do therefore unanimou≈øly re≈øolve to apply our ≈øelves to his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, who with ≈øo great Kindne≈øs to the≈øe Kingdoms, ≈øo Va≈øt Expence and ≈øo much hazard to his own Per≈øon, hath undertaken (by endeavouring to procure a Free Parliament) to re≈øcue us, with as little Effu≈øion of Chri≈øtian Blood as po≈ø≈øible, from imminent Dangers of Popery and Slavery.

And, we do hereby declare, That we will with our utmo≈øt Endeavours a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Highne≈øs in the obtaining ≈øuch a Parliament, with all ≈øpeed, wherein our Laws, our Liberties, and our Pro≈øperities may be ≈øecured; the Church of England in particular, with a due. Liberty to Prote≈øtant Di≈ø≈øenters; and in general; the Prote≈øtant Religion and Intere≈øt, over the whole World may be ≈øupported and encouraged; to the
Glory of God, the Happine≈øs of the E≈øtabli≈øhed Government, in the≈øe Kingdoms, and the advantage of all Princes, and State, in Chri≈øtendom, that may be herein concerned.

In the mean time we will endeavour to pre≈øerve, as much as in us lies, the Peace and Security of the≈øe great and populous Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter, and the parts adjacent, by taking Care to di≈øarm all Papi≈øts, and ≈øecure all Je≈øuits, and Romi≈øh Prie≈øts, who are in or about the ≈øame; and if there be any thing more to be performed by us; for the promoting His Highne≈øs's Generous Intentions for the publick Good, we ≈øhall he ready to doe it as Occa≈øion ≈øhall require.

div.p: This was ≈øigned by the two Arch-Bi≈øhops, five Bi≈øhops, and Twenty two Noblemen; and it was there concluded, that the Earl of Pembroke, the Lord Vi≈øcount Weymouth, the Lord Bi≈øhop of Ely, and the Lord Culpepper, ≈øhould forthwith attend his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, with the ≈øaid Declaration; and at the ≈øame time acquaint him with what was farther done at that Meeting.

The Lords having left the Guild Hall, the Lord Mayor, Court of Aldermen, and the Common Council a≈ø≈øembled, and among≈øt other Matters it was agreed by Vote, that an Humble Addre≈øs ≈øhould in their Names, and on the behalf of the City, be pre≈øented to His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, In haec verba.

q.p: WE taking into Con≈øideration Your Highne≈øs's fervent Zeal for the Prote≈øtant Religion, manife≈øted to the World in your many and hazardous Enterpri≈øes; which it hath plea≈øed Almighty God to ble≈øs you with miraculous ≈øucce≈øs, we render our deepe≈øt thanks to the Divine Maje≈øty for the ≈øame, and beg leave to pre≈øent our humble thanks to your Highne≈øs particularly, for your appearing in Arms in this Kingdom; to carry on, and perfect your glorious De≈øign, to re≈øcue England, Scotland, and Ireland, from Popery and Slavery; and in a Free Parliament to e≈øtabli≈øh the Religion, the Laws, and Liberties of the≈øe Kingdoms upon a ≈øure and la≈øting Foundation.

We have hitherto lookt for ≈øome Remedy for tho≈øe Oppre≈ø≈øions and imminent Dangers we, together with our Prote≈øtant Fellow Subjects, labour under, from His Maje≈øties Conce≈ø≈øions and Concurrences with your Highne≈øs's ju≈øt and pious purpo≈øes, expre≈ø≈øed in your Gracious Declaration;

But herein finding our ≈øelves finally di≈øappointed by His Maje≈øties with-drawing him≈øelf, we pre≈øume to make your Highne≈øs our Refuge, and do in the Name of the Capital City, implore your Highne≈øs's Protection; and mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech your Highne≈øs to vouch≈øafe to repair to this City, where your Highne≈øs will be received with univer≈øal Joy and Satisfaction.

div.p: This Addre≈øs being highly approved by all pre≈øent, Four Aldermen, and Eight Commoners were appointed to wait upon his Highne≈øs, and pre≈øent him with the ≈øaid Addre≈øs; and accordingly it was pre≈øented, and very favourably received.

And the Lieutenancy of the City of London, being the ≈øame day a≈ø≈øembled, drew up an Addre≈øs to be pre≈øented to his Highne≈øs, on the behalf of them≈øelves, the Militia, &c. which being to the ≈øame Effect with the former, we think it needle≈øs to in≈øert.

This Addre≈øs was delivered by four of the Members of the Lieutenancy, and very kindly received by his Highne≈øs. By this time the Earl of Fever≈øham, then commanding the King's Forces, having received His Maje≈øties Letter, by which he under≈øtood he had withdrawn him≈øelf; and wherein he received ≈øuch Orders as the King thought nece≈ø≈øary to leave, he ≈øent to acquaint his His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange with what had happened in the following Letter

body.p: HAving received this Morning a Letter from His Maje≈øty, with the unfortunate News of his Re≈øolution to go out of England, and that he is actually gone, I thought my ≈øelf obliged, being at the Head of his Army, having received his Maje≈øties Orders to make no oppo≈øition again≈øt any Body, to let your Highne≈øs know (with the Advice of the Officers here) ≈øo ≈øoon as it was po≈ø≈øible, to hinder the Misfortune of Effu≈øion of Bloud: I have ordered already, to that purpo≈øe, all the Troups that are under my Command, which ≈øhall be the la≈øt Order they ≈øhall receive from me, &c.

div.p: This Order cau≈øed the Troups to fall off and disband, as well becau≈øe they knew them≈øelves without a Head, as not knowing how to come by their Pay, if they continued in the Service; and indeed many of the Foot Soldiers were driven to great extremity; being by this Disbanding de≈øtitute of Moneys, Lodging, and other necce≈ø≈øaries, and had for a while nothing to ≈øub≈øi≈øt, but the Charity of the People: And although the Iri≈øh Battalion ≈øeemed for a time ob≈øtinate to continue in Arms, yet the Commands they received from His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, and the nece≈ø≈øity that they felt, con≈øtrained them to ≈øubmit.

This Di≈øper≈øing of the Solders, made his Highne≈øs publi≈øh a Declaration, requiring all Commanders in chief, by Beat of Drum, or otherwi≈øe, to call together the ≈øeveral Officers and Soldiers, belonging to their re≈øpective Regiments, Troups, and Companies, in ≈øuch places as they ≈øhould find mo≈øt convenient for their Rendezvouz; and there to keep them in good Order and Di≈øcipline. And likewi≈øe directing and requiring all ≈øuch Officers, and Soldiers, forthwith to repair to ≈øuch places as ≈øhall
be appointed for that purpo≈øe by the re≈øpective Collonels, or Commanders in chief.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed in the Army, the multitude got together in divers places, ≈øpoiling and demoli≈øhing the Popi≈øh Ma≈øs-Hou≈øes, and Chapels; much defacing the Dwelling Hou≈øes of ≈øeveral Eminent Papi≈øts, who were fled for fear of being ≈øecured; and though the Magi≈øtrates laboured to quiet the Tumults and Di≈øorders of this kind, yet they found their Authority too feeble, till the Mobile had ≈øpent their rage in London, &c. They pull'd down the Convent of Monks in St. John's, which had been two Years Building at a va≈øt Expence, and Burnt the greate≈øt part of the Timber and Materials in Smithfield; having before ≈øiezed ≈øome of the Goods, as they were removing them, and burnt them in Holborn: They likewi≈øe defaced and demoli≈øhed the Chapels in Lime-≈øtrect and Lincolns-Inn Fields, with that of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour's at Wild-hou≈øe, where violently breaking into his Excellency's Lodgings, they got great ≈øtore of Plunder, in Plate, Money, and ri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Goods, &c. And in like manner they ≈øerved the Lodgings of the Re≈øident of
Florence, in St. James's Hay-Market; and offered divers Affronts and Abu≈øes to other Hou≈øes, gathering in ≈øuch Numbers from all parts, that it is almo≈øt incredible; in≈øomuch, that neither the Watches, nor Trained-Bands, thought it ≈øafe to oppo≈øe the Torrent; but the next day it was pretty, well allayed and then ≈øearch was made in divers places for ≈øuch as were fled from Ju≈øtice; and among≈øt others, to the no ≈ømall wonder of the People, the Lord Chancellour Jeffries was taken, at a blind Hou≈øe in Hope and Anchor Alley in Wapping, di≈øgui≈øed like a Sailer, and endeavouring to make his e≈øcape in a Ve≈ø≈øel that lay by the Key for Hamborough; and being brought before the Lord Mayor, who by rea≈øon of an Indi≈øpo≈øition that then ≈øiezed him, not being capable of examining the Matter, he was contented to go the Tower to pre≈øerve him≈øelf from the rage of the Rabble, that loudly threatened him with De≈øtruction; and being guarded thither with a Detachment of the Trained-Bands was received by the Lieutenant of the Tower; to whom, upon Notice, the Lords at White-Hall ≈øent a Warrant of Commitment, to keep the Body of George Lord
Jefferies, Baron of Wem, in ≈øafe Cu≈øtody, &c.

On the 4th. of December, His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange came to Wind≈øor about Three in the Afternoon, and was received with mo≈øt profound re≈øpect and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion by the Mayor and Aldermen in their Formalities, the Steward of that Corporation Congratulating his Arrival in a mo≈øt Elegant Speech; and afterwards he went to the Prince of Denmark's Lodgings, prepared for his Reception: And whil≈øt His Highne≈øs was preparing for London, News came that the King attempting to pa≈øs the Seas at Fever≈øham in di≈øgui≈øe, was ≈øtay'd by ≈øome of the Towns-men who were fearching for ≈øuch as were endeavouring the like, who being ignorant that it was his Maje≈øty, carried him in a rude manner to a hou≈øe in the Town; taking from him ≈øome Jewels, con≈øiderable quantity of Gold, and his Crucifix of a great Value: Not did tho≈øe rude People de≈øi≈øt from their Incivilities, till a Gentleman coming to ≈øee the Pri≈øoners they had taken, and knowing the King, fell on his Knees to pay him duty; whereat the multitude being ≈øtrangely ≈øurprized, a great
part of them retired, and others begged his Maje≈øties Pardon, offering to re≈øtore what they had taken from him; but he would not receive his Gold again, but gave it them in Genero≈øity, as a free Gift.

The Lords at White-Hall hearing of his Maje≈øty's being at Fever≈øham, ≈øent to wait upon him, and pray him to return to his Palace Royal; to which he ≈øeemed not at fir≈øt inclinable; though being pre≈ø≈øed to a Return, he at la≈øt con≈øented. But His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange having fully determined to come to London with all ≈øpeed, he thought it in many re≈øpects improper for the King and him≈øelf to be there at one and the ≈øame time in the pre≈øent State of Affairs; upon notice his Maje≈øty was returning, he ≈øent Mon≈øieur Zule≈øtein to meet him on the way, and intreat him to return to Roche≈øter; but Mon≈øieur Zule≈øtein mi≈ø≈øing him by taking another Road than that by which he came, the King arrived at White-hall the 16th. of December in the Evening, attended by divers Noblemen, and a Guard of Hor≈øe; and from thence he ≈øent the Lord Fever≈øham to invite his Highne≈øs to come to St. James's, and
take that Palace as his Place of Re≈øidence, with what number of Troups he thought convenient.

The Prince deliberating upon this, with the Lords at Wind≈øor, the day before he had appointed to be in Town; and having communicated to them the Me≈ø≈øage, and left them to debate the matter; it was agreed that it was in no kind advi≈øable, for the Prince to accept the Invitation; and there being on the other ≈øide a nece≈ø≈øity the Prince ≈øhould be in Town, the next day the Lords thought the ≈øhortne≈øs of time could admit no better Expedient, than that the King might be de≈øired to remove to ≈øome Place within a rea≈øonable di≈øtance from London; upon which Ham, a Hou≈øe belonging to the Dutche≈øs of Lander-dale, was concluded on; and in order to this, a Paper was drawn, and Signed by the Prince, viz.

body.p:
WE de≈øire you the Lord Marque≈øs of Hallifax, the Earl of Shrewsbury, and the Lord Delamere, to tell the King that it is thought convenient, for the greater ≈øafety of his Per≈øon, that he do remove move to Ham, where he ≈øhall be attended by Guards, who will be ready to pre≈øerve
him from any di≈øturbance.

By this time the Earl of Crauford, the Earl of Louthian, and others, being come to Town, the former of the≈øe Earls de≈øired his Highne≈øs that they might ≈øub≈øcribe the Addre≈øs, which was accordingly granted, his Highne≈øs leaving ≈øignal marks of a high ≈øatisfaction in the Countenances of the noble A≈ø≈øembly, which demon≈øtrated how much they were plea≈øed with his An≈øwer; nor no ≈øooner did the News arrive at Edinburgh,

The Engli≈øh Soldiers many of them having been impo≈øed upon by ill affected Per≈øons to doubt their Pay, &c. his Highne≈øs was plea≈øed to put forth a publick A≈ø≈øurance, that he had taken care for the ≈øatisfying and making good to every Officer, and Soldier, their full Pay and Arrears, due to them untill the fir≈øt day of January, 1688. and for the making con≈øtant and punctual payment of Sub≈øi≈øtence Money, and clearing of the Army in the u≈øual method, without any the lea≈øt diminution of their former Pay, ordering all Officers to repair to their re≈øpective Commands, and Soldiers to their Quarters and Rendezvouz, under ≈øuch penalties as a refu≈øal may incur; and that nothing might be wanting on his part, His Highne≈øs in another Paper gave the like notice and a≈ø≈øurance to the Sea-men belonging to the Engli≈øh Fleet, under the Command of the Lord Dartmouth. And now the Royal African Company intreated his Highne≈øs to doe them the Honour of taking upon him to be their Governour for the en≈øuing year,
and made him a Pre≈øent of 1000 l. in their Stock, worth 2000 l. which he very favourably accepted.

Now the great Convention, on which the Eyes of all Europe are fixed, drawing near, the Members who were cho≈øen and returned came to Town, the Hou≈øes were prepared for the Reception of the augu≈øt A≈ø≈øembly, and on the 21th. of January the High-Sheriff, with all the con≈øiderable Gentlemen of E≈øtate in the County of Cambridge, having unanimou≈øly entered into an A≈ø≈øociation, whereby they ≈øolemnly engage them≈øelves to ≈øtand by His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, with their Lives and Fortunes, in his glorious De≈øign of Redeeming the≈øe Kingdoms from Popery and Slavery, Mr. Cotton of Madingly was to wait upon His Highne≈øs, and pre≈øented it in the Name of the County, to which His Highne≈øs was plea≈øed to return a very gracious An≈øwer.

On the 22th. of January, according to the grand Appointment, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, the Lord Marque≈øs of Halifax officiated the Place of Speaker, in the Hou≈øe of Lords, and the Commons cho≈øe Henry Powle E≈øq to
be their Speaker, who accordingly took his place: After which a Letter from his H ‚Ä¢ ghne≈øs the Prince of Orange was read in both Hou≈øes on the Occa≈øion of their Meeting, viz.

body.p: I Have endeavoured to the utmo≈øt of my power to perform what was de≈øired from me, in order to the publick Peace, and ≈øafety, and I do not know that any thing hath been omitted which might tend to the pre≈øervation of them, ≈øince the Admini≈øtration of Affairs was put into my hands; it now lieth upon you to lay the Foundation of a firm ≈øecurity for your Religion, your Laws, and Liberties.

p.hi: I do not doubt but that by ≈øuch a full and free Repre≈øentative of the Nation as is now met, the Ends of my Declaration will be attained; and ≈øince it hath plea≈øed God hitherto to ble≈øs my good Intentions with ≈øo great ≈øucce≈øs, I tru≈øt in him that he will complete his own Work, by ≈øending a Spirit of Peace and ∆≤nion to influence your Coun≈øels, that no interruption may be given to a happy and la≈øting ≈øettlement.

body.p: The dangerous condition of the Prote≈øtant Intere≈øt in Ireland, requiring a large and ≈øpeedy ≈øuccour, and the pre≈øent ≈øtate of things abroad, oblige me to tell you, That next to the danger of un≈øea≈øonable Divi≈øion among≈øt your ≈øelves, nothing can be ≈øo fatal as too great delay in your Con≈øultations; the States, by whom I have been enabled to re≈øcue this Nation, may ≈øuddenly feel the in Effects of it, both by being too long deprived of the Service of their Troups, which are now here, and of your early a≈ø≈øi≈øtence again≈øt a powerfull Enemy, who hath declar'd War again≈øt them; and as England is by Treaty already engaged to help them, upon any ≈øuch Exigencies, ≈øo I am confident that their chearfull Concurrence to pre≈øerve this Kingdom with ≈øo much hazard to them≈øelves, will meet with all the Returns of Friend≈øhip and A≈ø≈øi≈øtence which may be expected from you, as Prote≈øtants and Engli≈øh men, when ever their Condition ≈øhall require it.

div.p:
This Letter being read, and unanimou≈øly approved and applauded, with the highe≈øt ≈øatisfaction, the Lords and Commons re≈øolved upon an Addre≈øs, to be pre≈øented to his Highne≈øs, of Thanks for what he had done, and humbly to de≈øire him to continue the Admini≈øtration
of publick Affairs, till farther application ≈øhould be made by them to his Highne≈øs, Which Addre≈øs being pre≈øented to his Highne≈øs on Wedne≈øday the 22th. of January, he was plea≈øed to return them this An≈øwer, viz.

body.p: I Am glad that what I have done hath plea≈øed you, and ≈øince you de≈øire me to continue the Admini≈øtration of Affairs, I am willing to accept it; I mu≈øt recommend to you the con≈øideration of Affairs abroad, which maketh it fit for you to expedite your Bu≈øine≈øs, not only for making a Settlement at home upon a good Foundation, but for the ≈øafety of all Europe.

div.p: After this an Order was pa≈ø≈øed on the ≈øame day, That no Papi≈øt, or reputed Papi≈øt, ≈øhould pre≈øume to come into the Lobby, Painted Chamber, Court of Reque≈øts, or We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, during the ≈øitting of the Convention.

Then the Speaker of the honourable Hou≈øe of Commons put the Hou≈øe in
mind of the pre≈øent Affairs of the Kingdom, recommending the ≈øpeedy care of providing for its ≈øafety to the re≈øpective Repre≈øentatives, declaring The danger it was lately in, and putting them in mind of the de≈øperate State of Ireland; He farther minded them of the growth of France, and concluded in recommending the≈øe things to their prudent Care and Conduct, &c.

After the≈øe and other weighty con≈øiderations, an Order was made by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons, for a publick Thank≈øgiving, for our great and miraculous deliverance from the imminent Danger that ≈øo lately hung over our Heads.
Thur≈øday the 31≈øt. of January in≈øtant, being appointed for the City of London, and Ten Miles di≈øtance, and Thur≈øday the 14th. day of February following for the re≈øt of the Kingdom.

Thus all things concurring towards a happy Settlement, and Uniting of Prote≈øtants, &c. in England and Scotland, let us look a little into the Affairs of Ireland, which as yet has not the like pro≈øpect, as being very much inhabited by Native Iri≈øh Papi≈øts, devoted Enemies to the Prote≈øtant Religion. The Earl of
Tyrconnel, whom the King had made his Lieutenant, or Deputy of that Kingdom, taking the advantage of the hurry and di≈øorder the Affairs of England had put the People into, magnified their Fears, and u≈øed his endeavours to gain them to a Revolt, but finding the Prote≈øtants in no wi≈øe forward to joyn or take part with him, he in≈øtantly ≈øent his Letters through all the Provinces and Countries, to cau≈øe the Gentry and Pea≈øants to take up Arms on the behalf of the King, and the defence of their Religion, declaring, if the King him≈øelf ≈øhould in that juncture de≈øire it, he would not deliver up his Sword; ≈øo that leaving no endeavours to ≈øtrengthen him≈øelf untried, he in a ≈øhort time drew together a formidable Army, and ≈øecured divers Places of ≈øtrength, fortifying the Hou≈øes and Ca≈øtles of ≈øeveral Noblemen; whereupon, it was thought fit to ≈øend to him, and know his Intentions; but no farther ≈øatisfaction, at that time, could be gained, than that he was re≈øolved to ≈øtand for the King's Intere≈øt, and expect his Commands, &c. and accordingly upon notice that he, upon his a ≈øecond time withdrawing him≈øelf, was in France, the Report went currant, that
he ≈øent thither to know his Plea≈øure; in the mean while, though he offered no open Ho≈øtilities to the Prote≈øtants, yet in many Places he oppre≈ø≈øed them by Quartering his Soldiers at di≈øcretion in their Hou≈øes, ≈øeizing their Arms, and taking Ho≈øtages.

His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange having taken upon him, at the reque≈øt of the Lords and Commons, the farther Admini≈øtration of Government in Civil and Military Affairs, proceeded to the mo≈øt effectual meanes for the better ≈øetling the Army, and taking care for their Payment; and the better to a≈ø≈øure them, and encourage men of worth and true Valour, the ≈øale of Offices, or Military Employments are laid a≈øide.

And now the Wi≈ødom of the Nation having thought it, as we head, nece≈ø≈øary to have the pre≈øence of her Royal Highne≈øs the Prince≈øs of Orange in England, upon this great juncture of Affairs, thereupon a Convoy of Men of War, as well Engli≈øh as Dutch, was ordered to wait upon her till her Equipage could be got in a readine≈øs and the Wind ≈øerved to bring over her Highne≈øs, &c.

During the Joy of the People, in expectation or the Arrival of her Royal
Highne≈øs, and the preparations for her Reception, we had News from France that the King and Queen of England were frequently vi≈øited by the French Nobility, and entertained with the accu≈øtomed Grandeur; and that the French King gave out that he would have extraordinary Forces in the Field, early in the Spring, to oppo≈øe the gathering Armies of the Confederate Princes, and States of Holland, promi≈øing to him≈øelf tho≈øe advantages which only Time can make out, or determine: In oppo≈øition to which, and to di≈øable him in the le≈ø≈øening his Revenues, an Addre≈øs was agreed on by the honourable Convention, A≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, upon the great emergency of Affairs, to de≈øire and intreat his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange to i≈ø≈øue out his Proclamation for the prohibiting the Importation of French Commodities, and the going out of any Ships hence for France, farther recommending the State of Ireland, as its pre≈øent Condition requires, to his Care. On Wedne≈øday the 30th. of January, being the anniver≈øary Solemnity for the Murther of King Charles I. Dr. Sharp, Dean of Norwich, Preached before the Hou≈øe at St. Margarets We≈øtmin≈øter; and
on Thur≈øday the 31th. of January, the day appointed for Thank≈øgiving, in the City of London, and Ten miles round it, for the ≈øucce≈øs of his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, in the miraculous Deliverance he brought this Kingdom, &c. Dr. Gilbert Burnet, now Bi≈øhop of Salisbury, according to the de≈øire of the Hou≈øe, Preached before them in the ≈øame Church, there being a numerous A≈ø≈øembly, who at the clo≈øe of that Sermon expre≈ø≈øed an extraordinary ≈øatisfaction, the whole cour≈øe of it being managed with much Learning and Prudence, in every re≈øpect ≈øuitable to the occa≈øion of the day, and the Prayers appointed were read in the other Churches, with the ≈øame acceptation.

And becau≈øe the ≈øixth of February was at hand, to prevent the Thank≈øgiving formerly appointed to be held on that day, an Order of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, bearing date the ≈øecond of the ≈øame Month, was made publick in the≈øe words:

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, that the Day of Thanksgiving on the 6th. of February In≈øtant, on which Day the late
King James II. came to the Throne, ≈øhall not be ob≈øerved in this Kingdom.

Things being in this forwardne≈øs, a great many Citizens of London and We≈øtmin≈øter appeared in the Court of Reque≈øts with two Petitions, one to the Lords, and another to the Commons, both to this Effect, viz. That they mo≈øt humbly de≈øired that his mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange might be speedily ≈øetled in the Throne, by who≈øe Courage, Conduct, and Reputation, the Nation and the Prote≈øtant Religion might be defended from Enemies abroad and at home. That Ireland might be re≈øcued from its deplorable Condition, and finally the Kingdoms ≈øetled on a la≈øting foundation in Peace and Liberty.

The≈øe being received, and many weighty Con≈øiderations urging it, her Royal Highne≈øs's Coming over was ha≈øtened, and being on her Departure for England, the States General, the States of Holland, the Council of State, the Courts of Ju≈øtice, and all other Colleges, either in Body, or by their Deputies, made their Complements to her on the Occa≈øion; and the like was done by foreign Mini≈øters, and all other Per≈øons
of Quality; and at her Leaving the Hague, the Magi≈øtrates entreated that the Burghers might attend her in Arms; but She excu≈øed it; however the States of Holland appointed three of their Body to wait upon her Royal Highne≈øs to the place of her Embarquing; ≈øending Orders to the Sieur d' Allemonde, and the Ships under his Command, to joyn Admiral Herbert, who from England attended her with a Squadron of Men of war, and ≈øundry Yatches, for the better conveniency of Tran≈øportation; and having a pro≈øperous Gale, on the 12th. of February, in the afternoon She ≈øafely arrived at White-Hall, having been ≈øaluted by the Guns of the Forts, Ships in the road and tho≈øe of the Tower, where the Royal Banner was di≈øplayed, and by that Example the Ships likewi≈øe had put out their Flags and Streamers.

Great was the Joy upon the ≈øafe Landing of her Royal Highne≈øs, as appeared by the repeated Acclamations of the People, and other publick Demon≈øtrations; and that Night She received the Complements of the chief Per≈øons of Quality. And now the Two Hou≈øes thought it no longer nece≈ø≈øary to delay Proclaiming the Prince and Prince≈øs King and Queen of England, ≈øo that having
at large declared the Rea≈øons for the Abdication of James II. laying down therein the Illegalities in former Proceedings and Mi≈øcarriages in Government, &c. they came to a Re≈øolve, That William and Mary, Prince and Prince≈øs of Orange, ≈øhould be Declared King and Queen of England, France, and Ireland, with all the Dominions thereunto belonging, to hold the Crown, and Royal Dignity of the ≈øaid Kingdoms & Dominions to them, during their Lives and the Life of the Survivor of them; and that the ≈øole and full Exerci≈øe of the Regal Power be only in, and executed by the Prince in the Name of Him≈øelf and the Prince≈øs, during their joynt Lives; and after their Decea≈øes, the Crown and Royal Dignities of the Kingdoms and Dominions, to be to the Heirs of the Body of the Prince≈øs; and for default of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, to the Prince≈øs Ann of Denmark, and the Heirs of her Body; and for default of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, to the Heirs of the Body of the Prince of Orange.

And praying the Prince and Prince≈øs to accept this, accordingly the following Oaths were appointed to be taken by ≈øuch Per≈øons of whom the Oaths of
Allegiance and Supremacy might be required by Law; and farther, that the former Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy be Abrogated: After which the Oaths were Enacted, viz.

q.p: I A. B. do ≈øincerely Promi≈øe and Swear, That I will be faithfull, and bear true Allegiance to their Maje≈øties, King William and Queen Mary.

I A. B. do Swear, That I do from my Heart Abhor, Dete≈øt, and Abjure, as Impious and Heretical, this damnable Doctrine, and Po≈øition, that Princes, Excommunicated or deprived by the Pope, or any Authority of the See of Rome, may be Depo≈øed or Murthered by their Subjects, or any other what≈øoever. And I do declare, That no Foreign Prince, Per≈øon, Prelate, State, or Potentate, hath or ought to have any Juri≈ødiction, Power, Superiority, Preeminence, or Authority, Eccle≈øia≈øtical, or Spiritual, within this Realm.

div.p:
The≈øe and others, too many to be here in≈øerted, being the Proceedings in order to the Proclaiming, on the 13th. of
February, the Two Hou≈øes went to acquaint the Prince and Prince≈øs of Orange, in the Banqueting-Hou≈øe, with what they had done; and having received Their Con≈øent thereto, the Lords and Commons, about Eleven of the Clock, went down to White-Hall Gate, where the Officers at Arms, Serjeants at Arms, Trumpets, and other Per≈øons, concerned in the Solemnity, being a≈ø≈øembled, by order of the Duke of Norfolk, Earl Mar≈øhal of England, St. Thomas St. George, Knight, Garter Principal King at Arms, having received a Proclamation, and the Officers at Arms being Ordered by the Hou≈øe of Lords forthwith to Proclaim it, York Herauld, after the Trumpets had thrice Sounded, Proclaimed it at White-Hall Gate, Garter Reading it to him by Periods in the Pre≈øence of the Lords and Commons, and a great Concour≈øe of People, &c. and at the end of the Proclamation the Palace, and all the adjacent Places, re≈øounded with the Eccho of a general Joy, and loud Satisfaction; and from thence in Excellent Order they proceeded to Temple-Bar where (as the Ceremony is in this Ca≈øe, according to Cu≈øtome) finding the Gates ≈øhut, two of the Officers
at Arms, attended by a Serjeant at Arms, and two Trumpets, knocked, and thereupon the Sheriffs of London and Middle≈øex being informed of the Occa≈øion of their Coming, Ordered them to be opened, and the whole Proceeding entered (except the Bailiff of We≈øtmin≈øter, and his Men, who returned, as being obliged not to pa≈øs the Bounds of their Liberty,) and here the Lord Mayor, Recorder, and Aldermen, received them in their Formalities, and a ≈øecond Proclamation was made between the two Temple-Gates, in the ≈øame manner and order; and the Lord Mayor, Sheriffs, Aldermen, &c. falling into the Proceding, they pa≈ø≈øed to Wood-≈øtreet-end in Cheap≈øide and there made a third Proclamation, and a fourth before the Royal Exchange in Cornhill, every time concluding with Shouts and Acclamations of the People, who filled the Streets, Balconies, and Windows, in great multitudes, and to prevent any Di≈øorder, ≈øuch an Exce≈øs of Joy might occa≈øion, four Regiments of the City Militia were in Arms to line the Way, for the better conveniency of Pa≈ø≈øage.

The Pomp of the Solemnity being over, and night coming on, the Bells and
Bonfires made a ≈øecond Proclamation of the Peoples Satisfaction, and the news, by the Thundering of the Cannon, was in a ≈øhort time carried, by taking the fire of the Guns from one Ship to another, beyond the I≈øland it ≈øelf; nor were their curious Fire-works and Devices wanting on this Occa≈øion; and the Solemnity was more e≈øpecially concluded with Magnificent Entertainments at Court; and ≈øoon after their Maje≈øties, with the like Demon≈øtration of Joy, were Proclaimed in all the Cities and Principal Burghs, Towns of England, and Dominion of Wales.

On the 15th. of February His Maje≈øty returned both Hou≈øes a very Gracious An≈øwer to their Declaration, wherein he expre≈ø≈øed Him≈øelf highly ≈øatisfied with what they had done, and was plea≈øed to promi≈øed them the utmo≈øt of his Care and Protection, for the pre≈øervation of their Religion, Laws, and Liberties: and that He would be willing to concurr with them in any thing that ≈øhould be for the Good of the Kingdom, and to doe all that in him lay to advance the Glory and Welfare of the Nation.

About this time a Complaint was
made, that divers di≈øorderly Per≈øons, notwith≈øtanding a former Declaration, ≈øtrictly enjoyning the contrary, continued to de≈øtroy the Deer, Timber, and Underwoods, in divers Cha≈øes and Forre≈øts. Farther Notice was publi≈øhed, Commanding all Mayors, Sheriffs, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, and others, whom it might concern, to ≈øeize, or cau≈øe Per≈øons found offending therein to be ≈øeized and proceeded again≈øt, according to Law, without expectation of Pardon, if found guilty. And farther con≈øidering that divers had attempted to e≈øcape to Tyrconnel in Ireland, to aid him in oppre≈ø≈øing the Prote≈øtants of that Kingdom, Orders were taken for ≈øtopping the Ports of Che≈øter, Beaumaris, and Holy-head, and other Ports, and Creeks, on the Iri≈øh Sea, and not to ≈øu≈ø≈øer any Per≈øon or Per≈øons what≈øoever to go for Ireland, unle≈øs tho≈øe by whom a Pa≈øs was produced from his Maje≈øty, or one of his Principal Secretaries of State.

The Recorder, Sheriffs, and Common Serjeant of London having been to wait on their Maje≈øties, by Order of the Lord Mayor and Common Council, to beg leave from them to attend their Maje≈øties to Congratulate their happy
Acce≈ø≈øion to the Throne, the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Commons, went in a Body, and had the favour of Waiting upon their Maje≈øties in the Banqueting-Hou≈øe, and were Graciou≈øly received, being admitted to Ki≈øs their Maje≈øties Hands. And now we received continual Relations of the Joy that was conceived throughout the whole Shires of England, &c. Upon the ≈øeveral Proclaimings of King William and Queen Mary, Expre≈ø≈øed by Ringing of Bells, making of Bonfires, and drinking their Healths.

On the 18th. of February in the morning the King went from White-Hall, in his Barge of State to the Parliament-Stairs, where he was received by ≈øeveral of the great Officers, and others, the Yeomen of the Guards, and Gentlemen Pentioners, making a Lane from the Water-≈øide to the Door going up into the Prince's Lodgings; the Proceedings being in this manner: Fir≈øt went the Officers at Arms, then the Noble-men, bearing white Staves, and after them Serjeants at Arms, the Garter King at Arms between two Gentlemen-U≈øhers, immediately before the Sword of State, which was born by the Duke of Somer≈øet, having on the Left hand the Duke of
Norfolk, Earl Mar≈øhal of England, with his Mar≈øhal's Staff, next went the Marque≈øs of Winche≈øter, bearing the Cup of State, then the King, followed by an Officer of the Guards, and other Per≈øons of Quality, the Gentlemen Pentioners clo≈øing the Rear; and his Maje≈øty being come into the Prince's Lodging, was inve≈øted with his Sur-coat and Mantle of Crim≈øon Velvet, bordered with Gold-Lace, and furred with Ermins, as al≈øo with the Collar of the Order of the Garter; and as ≈øoon as the Crown was placed upon His Head, the Officers at Arms, and the Serjeants at Arms entered the Hou≈øe of Lords, and the Noblemen, who preceded his Maje≈øty, having placed them≈øelves on each ≈øide of the Throne, and his Maje≈øty, who≈øe Train was born up by Noble-mens Elde≈øt Sons, being-≈øeated on the Throne, the Gentleman U≈øher of the Black Rod was commanded to ≈øummon up the Commons, who being accordingly introduced into the Hou≈øe of Peers, and their Speaker conducted to the Bar, with the u≈øual Formalities, and the Lords being in their Robes, His Maje≈øty made a mo≈øt Gracious ≈øpeech, in which he was plea≈øed to let them know how ≈øen≈øible he
was of their Kindne≈øs, and how much he valued the confidence they had repo≈øed in him; A≈ø≈øuring them that he would never do any thing that might le≈ø≈øen their good Opinion of him, putting them in mind of the Allies abroad, and the hazard they may run, e≈øpecially Holland, unle≈øs ≈øome ≈øpeedy Care were taken: That a good Settlement was nece≈ø≈øary at Home; particularly recommending to them the dangerous State of Ireland, and the Methods to their ≈øpedy con≈øideration.

On the 2d. of February the Lord Bi≈øhop on London, with the Clergy of the City, to the number of an 100 waited on their Maje≈øties with an humble Tender of their Fidelity and Duty, and being Graciou≈øly received, were admitted to ki≈øs their Maje≈øties Hands, the King at the ≈øame time being plea≈øed to give them a full A≈ø≈øurance of of his great Affection to the Church of England, and of all the Protection and Encouragement to them, for which he gave them his Royal Word; concluding with A≈ø≈øuring them, that they ≈øhould ever find it ≈øo, and they might depend upon it, the Hou≈øes re≈øolved into a free Parliament. His Maje≈øty went on the 23d. of February by Water to the Hou≈øe
of Lords, attended with the u≈øual Solemnity, and being in his Royal Robes, with the Crown on his Head, ≈øeated on the Throne, and the Commons being ≈øent for, His Maje≈øty gave the Royal A≈ø≈øent to an Act, for removing and preventing all Que≈øtions and Disputes about the A≈ø≈øembling and Sitting of the pre≈øent Parliament. And having di≈ørobed him≈øelf, he was attended to the Water-≈øide with the like Ceremony as before, and in the afternoon their Maje≈øties went to Hampton-Court.

On the 28th. of February two Proclamations were i≈ø≈øued forth by the King and Queen, the one at the Reque≈øt of the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons to apprehend Robert Brent, Gentleman, late of the Inner-Temple, charged with High Trea≈øon, who procuring him≈øelf to be Bailed had left them, and fled from Ju≈øtice, with the Reward of 200 l. to any per≈øon that ≈øhould di≈øcover or apprehend him, and tho≈øe that ≈øhould conceal, or further his E≈øcape, to be proceeded again≈øt with the utmo≈øt ≈øeverity according to Law.

The other for the bringing in and re≈øtoring of Arms that had been Embezled, or Lo≈øt, during the Di≈øorders and Di≈øbandings
among≈øt the Soldiers, that had been in pay under the late King James; and upon advice that the Earl of Tyrconnel laboured to draw the Iri≈øh more and more to his Party, and confirm tho≈øe that were already in Arms with him, by laying before them the Danger already incurr'd, their Maje≈øties, to leave them that ≈øhould ob≈øtinately per≈øi≈øt, without excu≈øe, i≈ø≈øued forth a Proclamation, offering among≈øt other things Pardon and Indemnity for all things, by tho≈øe of the Earl's Party, if they laid down their Arms, and retired them≈øelves to their re≈øpective Habitations, and Places of Abode, and there peaceably behaved them≈øelves as good Subjects ought to doe; as likewi≈øe that they ≈øhould upon this (ondition enjoy in full freedom their E≈øtates according to Law, and tho≈øe of the Roman Church, upon ≈øuch Con≈øideration to have all the Favour, for the private Exerci≈øe of their Religion that the Law allows, with a promi≈øe ≈øpeedily to call a Parliament in that Kingdom; but on the Contrary declaring them Rebels, and Traytors. &c. and their Lands and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions forfeited, and to be di≈øpo≈øed and di≈øtributed to tho≈øe that ≈øhould be Aiding,
and A≈ø≈øi≈øting in reducing the Kingdom to its due Obedience.

This Proclamation 'tis thought, whether hindred by Tyrconnel's violence from coming to the knowledge of the Vulgar, or creating a fear in his followers, made him fly to his La≈øt refuge of more ≈øtrictly di≈øarming the Prote≈øtants, as well tho≈øe in Cities that fell into his hands, as Gentlemen who were retired to their Hou≈øes, where his Soldiers committed ≈øundry Outrages of an high Nature, Robbing and Pillaging without remor≈øe or pity, though under a colour excu≈øed him≈øelf, by giving directions to the Magi≈øtrates to ≈øee that no wrong ≈øhould be done; however when Complaints were made, he urged nece≈ø≈øity compell'd his Men to doe what they did; yet the Prote≈øtants, e≈øpecially in the North, ≈øtood to their Arms, and repelled force by force, getting ≈øome ≈øupplies of Ammunition out of Scotland, keeping the Town of Sligo, and other places of ≈øtrength, with a Longing expectation of the Arrival of the Forces and nece≈ø≈øary Provi≈øions from England, to be thereby enable to carry on the War, and recover what has been taken from them by the Iri≈øh Papi≈øts.

And now the duty of Hearth mony being looked upon by the Commons, as a grievance to the Subjects, and repre≈øented as ≈øuch to his Maje≈øty, the King was plea≈øed to ≈øend a me≈ø≈øage that he left it to their con≈øiderations, either to regulate it, or to take it away, which was received with great ≈øatisfaction, and forthwith the thanks of the Hou≈øe were ordered to be returned his Maje≈øty for his gracious Me≈ø≈øage; and on the 1≈øt. of March in the Afternoon, the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, Waited upon his Maje≈øty in the Banqueting-hou≈øe and and there pre≈øented an Addre≈øs of thanks, wherein they expre≈ø≈øed the Joy and Satisfaction they conceived at ≈øo unpre≈øidented an offer, humbly craving leave to pre≈øent their A≈ø≈øurance, that they-would make ≈øuch gratefull and affectionate returns, as were ≈øuitable to his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Gracious Intentions, and be ≈øo carefull of the Support of the Crown that the World ≈øhould ≈øee, to the di≈øcouraging his Enemies, that his Maje≈øty reigns in the Hearts of his People, &c.

The Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament,
made likewi≈øe and Addre≈øs to his Maje≈øty, expre≈ø≈øing therein how highly they were ≈øen≈øible of their great and Signal deliverance, &c. And that being fully convinced of the re≈øtle≈øs Spirits, and continued Endeavours of his Maje≈øties and the Nations Enemies, for the Extirpation of the Prote≈øtant Religion, and the Subver≈øion of the Laws and Liberties, they unanimou≈øly declared, that they would Stand by, and A≈ø≈øi≈øt his Maje≈øty with their Lives and Fortunes, in Supporting his Allies abroad, in reducing Ireland, and in defence of the Prote≈øtant Religion of the Kingdom.

To this his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to return them a very Gracious An≈øwer, expre≈ø≈øing therein the valuable E≈øteem he had for Parliaments, and e≈øpecially for this, expre≈ø≈øing his Satisfaction of the Confidence and Tru≈øt they had repo≈øed in him, and that it ≈øhould be his Care never to give any Parliament cau≈øe of di≈øtru≈øt; and withall recommending to them the care of the Allies abroad, and minding them of the greate Expence the States of Holland had been at in the Expedition and Zeal they had to promote it, and to ≈øecond his Maje≈øties
Endeavours even with a neglect of their own Safety, not doubting but their Genero≈øity would not only enable him to make good his treaty with tho≈øe States, and repay what they actually layd out, and of which an account ≈øhould be given, but ≈øupport them to their utmo≈øt Ability again≈øt the power of their Enemies, con≈øidering both Intere≈øts were upon one and the ≈øame Bottom. As to ≈øafety, his Maje≈øty was likewi≈øe plea≈øed to mind them of Ireland, and to let them know, that in his opinion 20000 men would be required to render the reducing it ≈øhort and ea≈øie, as likewi≈øe ≈øetting out a Fleet which in conjunction with that of Holland, might be ≈øo entirely Ma≈øter of the Seas that nothing might be ≈øent from France to Ireland, or el≈øewhere, that might give a di≈øturbance to us or our Allies; farther recommending to their con≈øideration the ≈øettlement of the Revenues, that they might be collected without di≈øpute; promi≈øing that whatever ≈øhould be given in order to publick ends, ≈øhould be ≈øtrictly applyed to them, with many other Gracious expre≈ø≈øions; concluding that as they ≈øo freely offered to hazard all that is dear to them, ≈øo he would as freely expo≈øe
his Life for the Support of the Prote≈øtant Religion, and the Honour and Safety of the Nation.

And now the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Commons of the City of London, in Common Council a≈ø≈øembled as a grateful Acknowledgment to the Lords and Commons for their excellent Conduction in Affairs, and e≈øpecially their re≈øolution to a≈ø≈øi≈øt and ≈øtand by his Maje≈øty in ≈øupporting his Allies abroad, in reducing Ireland, in defence of the Prote≈øtant Religion, and Laws of the Kingdom, drew up two humble Addre≈ø≈øes of Thanks, one to the Lords, and the other to the Commons, which were pre≈øented and very kindly received; the fir≈øt of the≈øe was pre≈øented by the Recorder, and the la≈øt by the Sheriffs of the Honourable City, who were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with expre≈ø≈øions of high E≈øteem, &c. For the ≈øaid City an Addre≈øs of Thanks was likewi≈øe pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty by the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Council, upon his mo≈øt conde≈øcending and unparallell'd Goodne≈øs in the Me≈ø≈øage he was plea≈øed to ≈øend to the two Hou≈øes, in relation to the Duty of Hearth-mony, promi≈øing as bound in duty and great obligations, to be ready

About this time we had News that the greate≈øt part of the Regiment of Foot, late commanded by the Lord Dumbarton, and ≈øome Companies of Fuziliers, made a Mutiny near Ip≈øwych, and ≈øeized on the Money ≈øent down to pay them, with four Field-pieces, and refu≈øing to obey the King's Orders, marched away, doing great damage, and bringing a greater terrour upon the Country people, proclaiming King James, &c. whereupon both hou≈øes Addre≈ø≈øed his Maje≈øty that he would be plea≈øed to take ≈øuch effectual Cour≈øe, as in his Princely Wi≈ødom ≈øhould be thought fit for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing and bringing them to Ju≈øtice; and that in the mean time he would i≈ø≈øue out his Royal Proclamation, declaring them and their Adherents to be Rebels and Traitors, requiring all good Subjects to apprehend ≈øubdue and pro≈øecute them, &c. To which His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to an≈øwer, That he thanked both Hou≈øes for their Addre≈øs, and that he had ≈øent a Force of Hor≈øe and Dragoons ≈øufficient to ≈øuppre≈øs them, and that he would i≈ø≈øue out a Proclamation, as was de≈øired.

On the 16th of March His Maje≈øty went by water to the Hou≈øe of Lords, attended with the u≈øual Solemnity, and being in his Royal Robes, ≈øeated on the Throne, and the Commons ≈øent for up, His Maje≈øty gave the Royal A≈ø≈øent to an Act impowering him to apprehend ≈øuch Per≈øons as he ≈øhould find ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect are

Nor was it long e'er tho≈øe in Rebellion were brought under; for on the 19th of March the Regiments of Hor≈øe commanded by Sir John Lanier, and Collonel Lang≈øton, having joined the Dutch Troups of Hor≈øe and Dragoons, under the command of Lieutenant General Ginkell, and being informed that the Rebels were marching towards Seaford, they

Sir John Chapman, Lord Mayor of the City of London, dying on the of March, the worthy Thomas Pilkington E≈øq ≈øince being Knighted, elected Lord Mayor of that City for the remaining part of this Year, was on the 22d pre≈øented to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal, and afterwards ≈øworn at the Hu≈øtings, according to Cu≈øtome, and at five in the Afternoon was ≈øworn without the Tower Gate by the Right Honourable the Lord Lucas, chief Governour of the Tower, in pur≈øuance of their Maje≈øties Writ to him directed, and of the antient u≈øage at ≈øuch a time as the Exchequer Court is not holden at Westminster.

Having before made mention of the intended Convention in Scotland, and now the time appointed for its ≈øitting being come, it will not
≈øeem foreign to this Hi≈øtory to in≈øert ≈øome remarkable pa≈ø≈øages and Tran≈øactions relating to it and the Affairs of that Kingdom.

On the 14th of March, in obedience to the King of England's Letter, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and the Commons a≈ø≈øembled at Edinburgh in one Hou≈øe, as the Cu≈øtome is, and cho≈øe Duke Hamilton their Pre≈øident, and con≈øidering the Duke of Gourdon, a Roman Catholick, held the Ca≈øtle, who≈øe Cannon commanded the City, they made an Act, by which they empowered the Earls of Lothain and Tweddale to repair immediately to the Ca≈øtle of Edinburgh, and to require him and others of his per≈øua≈øion there, in the Name of the E≈øtates of this Kingdom, to remove out of that Ca≈øtle in twenty four hours after notice given, and to leave the Charge thereof to the next commanding Officer, being a Prote≈øtant, and that he, and tho≈øe that were with him, upon ≈øuch a compliance, ≈øhould have a≈ø≈øurance from the E≈øtates, to be ≈øecured and indempnified as to any thing they had acted in that or any other Station, contrary to Law, as being Papi≈øts.

to prevent di≈øorders, it was not inconvenient to command all per≈øons, who were not Inhabitants, nor immediately belonging to the Members of this Convention, to depart the place, but it was the Opinion of the Hou≈øe, that the Ca≈øtle, in the command of who≈øe Cannon the City was, ought to be fir≈øt ≈øurrendered, and for their better a≈ø≈øurance, a Committee was ordered to take care that no violation of the Peace were made. In the mean while two Letters came to the Convention, one from King William, and the other from the late King, of which only the fir≈øt was approved, and the Convention proceeded to take mea≈øures much like tho≈øe of England, declaring the Throne vacant, &c. and made preparation in order to fill it, ≈øuffering Men and Arms from England to enter that Kingdom, and it was in fine concluded, that King William and Queen Mary ≈øhould be crowned King and Queen of the Kingdom of Scotland, and the Crown offered them with an In≈øtrument of Government to ≈øettle and regulate particulars.

Whil≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed in Scotland, with others of the like purport, a Proclamation by the King and Queen was i≈ø≈øued out give to notice to the Peers, and ≈øuch as had any Claim, or Right of Tenure, that the Royal Solemnity of their Coronation was to be celebrated April 11th 1689. and on the 21≈øt of March his Maje≈øty going to the Hou≈øe of Lords, attended in the u≈øual ≈øolemnity, and being in his Royal Robes, ≈øeated on the Throne, and the Commons being ≈øent for up, gave his Royal A≈ø≈øent to an Act for granting a pre≈øent Aid to their Maje≈øties; and on the 31≈øt of March the Right Reverend Dr Gilbert Burnet, being before Bi≈øhop elect of Salisbury, was con≈øecrated according to the form pre≈øcribed in the Book of Common Prayer, in the Chapel of the Palace at Fulham, by the Lord Bi≈øhops of London, Winchester, Landaff, St A≈øaph, and Carli≈øle, by virtue of a Commi≈ø≈øion granted to them by his Grace the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury.

Frederick Mare≈øchal de Schomberg, General of his Maje≈øties Forces, and Ma≈øter General of the Ordnance; and the Right Honourable William Earl of Devonshire Lord Steward of his Maje≈øties Hou≈øhold, were elected Knight-Companions of the Order, and inve≈øted with the Garter and George, having been fir≈øt Knighted by the Sovereign with the u≈øual Ceremony; and Dr. Burnet, Bi≈øhop of Salisbury, was ≈øworn and admitted Chancellour of that Order. About this time His Maje≈øty cau≈øed notice to be given to all Prote≈øtant Officers that had been disbanded in Ireland, or lately quitted their Commands, they who were not yet employed in his Service to bring in their Names and Certificates of their former Commands, in order to their entering into Service, and Pay, &c. and to prevent fal≈øe and ≈øeditious Rumours, as to the le≈ø≈øening the Pay of ≈øuch Soldiers as ≈øhould be ≈øent over to the Low-Countries, His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to i≈ø≈øue forth his Proclamation to a≈ø≈øure them of full Engli≈øh Pay, and upon the Engli≈øh E≈øtabli≈øhment, as full to all Intents
as any other Regiments of his own Subjects of the ≈øame Quality, remaining in the Kingdom of England.

The Parliament a≈ø≈øembled at Westmin≈øter, having duly weighed and con≈øidered the high con≈øequence, as to the ≈øecurity of our Religion, Laws, &c. in the Efficacy of a Coronation, an Act being drawn up, it pa≈ø≈øed the Royal A≈ø≈øent the 9th of April, in the 1≈øt Year of their Maje≈øties Reigns, entituled, An Act for establi≈øhing the Coronation Oath.

Thus every thing being in a readine≈øs, and the expected day arrived, their Maje≈øties being come from White-Hall to We≈øtminster, the Heralds began to put the Proceedings in order, the Peers in the Lords Hou≈øe, and the Peere≈ø≈øes in the painted Chamber; ≈øo that about eleven in the morning their Maje≈øties and the whole Proceeding were conducted into We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, where at the upper end a Throne being erected, their Maje≈øties took their Seats under their Cloath of State on the in≈øide the Table, which done, the Ma≈øter of the Jewel-hou≈øe pre≈øented to the Lord High Con≈øtable the Sword of State, al≈øo the Sword Curtana, and the two pointed Swords in their order, who in the like order delivered them to the Lord Great Chamberlain, and he having drawn them out of the Scaboards,
